PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Will the minister give the millions of Australians who receive assistance under our social security safety net an unequivocal commitment to maintain the real value of pensions, payments to families—including sole parents—and all other social security benefits and entitlements?

—The Prime Minister has already made it very clear—prior to the election when addressing ACOSS late last year and again when being interviewed by Clive Robertson on radio—as to our commitments to the disadvantaged and to pensioners and others in Australia. I have made it clear, too. Nevertheless, I have said that we have inherited a system which is complex, unwieldy, and difficult to administer, and which causes mistakes to be made by departmental officers. It means that a lot of people do not know what they are entitled to. After 13 years of adhockery by the previous government it is time that these things be given a good look. That is what our government is intending to do.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. On 26 April on Sydney radio, in answer to a question about your campaign commitments, you said:

QUESTION.PARA: Anything is on the table at the moment. I can't rule things in or out at this stage.

Do I take it from your answer to my question that the unequivocal commitment given by your party during the election campaign to maintain the real value of pensions and other payments is now on the table, neither ruled in nor ruled out.

TALK.START.PARA: —The interview which the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate is referring to was a half hour interview in which I took great pains constantly to talk about our intention to maintain our commitments and to look after those in our society who are disadvantaged. To take anything out of context in a half hour interview is to mislead the Australian public. Our commitments are maintained. What I will not do, and would not do on that radio program, is discuss budget initiatives, which must wait for the budget.

—My question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer. After 18 consecutive quarters of economic growth why has Commonwealth debt increased by 400 per cent in four years to over $80 billion, why are national savings rates at lower rates than at the depths of the 1982‐83 recession and why are Australians faced with an $8 billion black hole in the budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Troeth for that very important question. The results of Labor's fiscal mismanagement are totally evident from the very disturbing figures that she has outlined. What those figures show is the inability of the former Labor government to effectively manage the finances of this country, to manage fiscal policy.

ANSWER.PARA: Let there be no doubt that the primary reason that we have a problem with our Commonwealth debt, that our national savings rates are at almost the lowest record in our history and that, with our current budget outlook, we are staring in the face of an $8 billion deficit, is the former Labor government's appalling record of fiscal ineptitude. Not only did Labor fail to save, they were massive dissavers. What is worse, they did not even recognise the problem they were creating. That is still the case. As recently as two days ago, Mr Beazley, at the Victorian state conference, said, `. . . this $8bn suggestion . . . It is a deceit . . . plain and simple, a deceit.' Further, he said:
This $8bn black hole is a chimera, put up for political purposes, a con job by Mr Costello.
On top of that, Mr Beazley has also been quoted as saying:
This notion of an $8 billion hole is largely a fraud . . . there are no statistics produced by Treasury that indicated that there was that dimension of a hole.

Nothing could be further from the truth. Mr Beazley is the one being deceitful. He and his Labor Party have a history of deceit. If Labor was not even willing to take the Australian public into their trust regarding the dire state of their budget, it is hard to believe that they would have done anything at all to tackle it. They would not have even taken the first honest step towards bringing the budget back into the black. Randall Markey of the West Australian was told by the opposition leader, Mr Beazley, that he—Mr Beazley—would not have released Treasury's revised figures if Labor had won. The Labor Party cannot hide from this.

TALK.START.PARA: —No‐one is listening to you.

—There are a lot of people out there who are listening to this. The Labor Party cannot hide from these figures, nor should they be allowed to. They should be required to hang every one of those $8 billion around their collective necks. Labor has to recognise and acknowledge that the coalition is simply fixing up the disastrous problems inherited from Labor. Labor had many opportunities during the election campaign to let the Australian people know about this appalling state of the budget deficit, but they chose the path of deceit. That is highlighted by Mr Beazley's statement on 1 February. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: We are operating in surplus and our projections are surpluses for the future.
He knew full well they were operating in deficit and their figures for the future were for a deficit as well.

Last week during an MPI Senator Sherry said in this place that pursuit of a budget surplus is an ideological pursuit. That highlights not only that Labor does not address the fiscal hole which is their own creation; they continue to act irresponsibly and treat it irresponsibly and ideologically. It has to be always kept in mind that it was the Labor mind‐set that led to five consecutive underlying budget deficits. That attitude has led to a 400 per cent increase in Commonwealth debt. How many more budget deficits does Labor need to wake up to the truth? (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs—and you will be expecting this one, minister. I refer to the answer that you gave Paul Bongiorno on Meet the Press on Sunday when he asked you about whether you intended to continue practising as a surgeon or become a full-time minister for Aboriginal affairs. In respect of continuing your practice as a surgeon, your reply was: `Well, I'd love to. Do you want Greg Norman to stop playing golf?' I am not quite sure what the relevance of that is. He is not a federal minister, but never mind. Do you agree with the statement that you want to continue to practise? We are not talking about finishing off procedures you had already started, minister; we are talking about what you said to Meet the Press about continuing your practice. Do you intend to give up being a surgeon or a minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thanks very much for that question because I want to put on the record that surgery to me is something that I love. It is a skill that is acquired over many years. It is an acquired skill—just as a golfer like Greg Norman might acquire a skill. You are asking to set a precedent that a skill that has been acquired over many years should be dispensed with.
—No.
—Yes, you are. It also is a hobby. Surgery, for me, is a hobby.
—You make the choice.

—Would you be kind enough to listen? Surgery, for me, is a hobby, to the extent that I have a letter from my accountant which says that I actually lost $13,000 last year in practising surgery because I enjoy it. It is a hobby. I practise it on Saturdays and Sundays when the relevant time occurs. I also do it because I have a requirement to follow up the patients that I have followed up for over 16 years in many respects. They have asked me whether I would continue their follow-up. If ultimately the decision is made—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Bob Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you telling me that you had no hobby as a minister, Senator Collins—no hobby whatsoever? Did you not have a hobby in that time that cost you money?

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of interjection is too loud.

—I am the first fellow of the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons to be in the Senate—let alone the ministry. If the decision is made that surgeons are precluded from retaining that skill, so be it. I will accept the judgment of the Prime Minister in that regard if you force that upon me. But it is not my wish to do so because I have a responsibility. I conducted a breast cancer clinic for 16 years before I entered parliament. It is costing me—
—Keep doing it, Senator.
—Do I have your permission to do so as a minister? Do I have the opposition's permission to do so?
—One or the other.

—So you cannot engage in anything else as a hobby? It costs me money to practise as a surgeon because I have to pay the secretarial staff. So you are going to be responsible for putting people out of work.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, that is what you are doing.
—Order! Senator Herron has been asked a question and we all have a duty to listen to the answer.

—I also ask Senator Collins: does nobody on that side, or on my side for that matter, have a farm or do any other outside activity? If you are going to preclude all surgeons from standing for parliament, then that will be required. That is what you are doing because that is the import of your question.

—The minister clearly does not have the first understanding of what principle is involved here. It was not the opposition that published these guidelines with great fanfare. It was your leader, the Prime Minister. I will have a bit more to say about ministers who own farms and about these guidelines when I note your answer. Following your answer, are you telling us, Minister, that the Prime Minister did not consult with you on these guidelines before they were promulgated, therefore ensuring you would not be in breach of them when you took your oath of office as a minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you really being serious, Senator Collins, with that question? Do you consider that the Prime Minister has to question every minister before their appointment? I had no idea I was going to get this portfolio, let alone be in the ministry. I had no idea that I was going to be selected. It is a great honour to be a minister within a government which will be in government for many years. I am proud of the fact that I am a member of the Howard ministry.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. Is the minister aware of calls from farmer and conservation groups throughout Australia for the need to restore and protect native vegetation in this country? Can the minister explain how the government's environmental package will tackle this vitally important issue and explain how that package will be funded?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator O'Chee for his important question. I inform the Senate that since European settlement Australia has lost much of its native vegetation cover. I mentioned at the weekend that some 15 billion trees have been removed from the Murray-Darling Basin alone, which has resulted in severe erosion, rising ground waters and a massive loss of biodiversity.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia is experiencing land degradation and biodiversity loss that significantly threatens our environment and the productive capacity of our agricultural land. The loss of vegetation is contributing to the degradation of our river systems and is putting at risk many of our native plant and animal species.

It is estimated that over 50 per cent of Australia's productive land now is in need of some form of repair. The direct annual cost of soil and water degradation alone is in excess of $1.4 billion. In addition the large-scale removal of native vegetation has disrupted the ground water balance, resulting in watertables rising across vast areas of Australia. This in turn leads to rising salinity.

About a third of Victoria's irrigation area has been salinised. Dry land agriculture has increased salt loads and concentrations in many rivers in south-east and south-west Australia. About one‐quarter of the cleared land in south-west Western Australia will become salinised over the next few decades and dry land salinity will also expand in the eastern uplands of Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland.

I could go on, but what I am doing is setting out the basis of a matter of great national consequence and a matter that simply was neglected by the last Labor government of this country. The program that we put down in our election commitment included $318 million towards a national vegetation initiative. Funding of the national vegetation initiative will be used to rehabilitate degraded land, strategically reduce watertables and hence lower salinity levels, protect and improve water quality, rehabilitate our coastal zone, protect biodiversity and prevent further loss of species, develop a strong and sustainable forest industry and provide sinks for greenhouse gases. It is therefore not surprising that it is overwhelmingly supported by both farmer organisations and conservation organisations.

How will we fund it? How are we able to fund it in a way that the Labor Party was not? Of course, through the sale of one‐third of Telstra. That will enable us to set up a $1 billion natural heritage trust—a capital fund to be reinvested in another major capital asset of Australia: its environmental wellbeing. Of that $1 billion fund, $318 million will go to this national vegetation initiative.

What a matter of great regret, what a national catastrophe, if the minority parties in this place join with the Labor Party, that so lost its morale and suffered disappointment as a result of the election, and this opportunity is lost—the opportunity to redress this damage to Australia's land, the salinity problems across southern Australia. That opportunity will be lost because you will not let us in this place set up that fund and reinvest part of the capital asset of one asset of Australia in another capital asset: the Australian natural environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. During an answer to a question from Senator Knowles last Thursday you said in reference to Labor's term in government that `many Australians have seen the value of their most prized possession, the family home, fall.' Could you please inform the Senate how much the value of the family home has fallen between 1983 and 1996 and where?

—If Senator Sherry is suggesting that the value of the family home for many Australians has not fallen as a result of Labor's policies and the consequent actions attempted to be taken by Labor to restore the mess that they created—and I am talking in particular about the recession that the former Prime Minister deliberately engineered in 1990—then he is not familiar with the facts. Of course the situation is that, in a competitive market, as is the case for housing, in some parts of Australia house values rise and in other parts they fall. I would have thought—
—Where? Give us an example.
—In real terms—
—Where?

—If you would stop mouthing, `Yeah, yeah, yeah; where, where, where,' you might get an answer. Let me give you an example. In relation to the area around some of the inner suburbs of Melbourne, including an area in which I live, and the western suburbs of Sydney, where in particular there are very low income families, the real value of housing has fallen over the period that Labor was in office. It goes up and it goes down with economic cycles. Even you, Senator Sherry, I am sure would appreciate that. But the fact is that in important areas of Australia, and in particular areas of middle and lower income Australia, values have fallen significantly in real terms. I am amazed that you are not aware of that.

—The Real Estate Institute of Australia market facts of major residential markets in Australia show an increase in the value of the average Australian home in every major market in Australia between 1984 and 1996. Why did you mislead the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Try and get a word out.

—It is pretty hard to get a word out with you rabble over there. That response by Senator Sherry is the clearest indication that he has given yet in the short time that he has been in this portfolio that he has no idea how to use statistics or how to interpret statistics. They are general figures. I simply repeat that there are important areas of Australia where the real value of housing, the key savings of many Australians, has fallen. I can only say that I am sorry for you, Senator Sherry, if you are not aware that that is the fact.

—My question is to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, you constantly imply that Telstra is inefficient. One of your most constant justifications for the partial privatisation of Telstra is to make it more efficient. What do you say, then, about last week's BZW Australia study of Telstra, which predicts that Telstra's profitability will rise by 65 per cent over the next three years and that this rise is linked to sound management? Do you agree with Telstra chief Frank Blount's comment last Friday when he was asked about the impact of privatisation on Telstra efficiency? He said, `It's not going to affect us one way or the other . . . the marketplace is driving this, not who owns the company.'

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did hear Mr Blount on PM . It was quite clear that what he was talking about was that the board's and senior management's commitment to efficiencies in the company was unrelated to the government's own agenda of privatisation. He has made it clear on a number of occasions that he is not wanting to take sides on the issue. He accepts the ruling of the government of the day. He was making it crystal clear—and I would have thought that you would have noticed this by now—that even Telstra itself acknowledges that it has to achieve a 30 per cent reduction in unit costs over the next two years because it is highly inefficient.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a very simplistic and essentially nonsensical response to say that, because you will increase your revenue, you must be efficient. They are totally unrelated. If you have a monopoly control of a market, you can charge what you like. That is what we have seen with ISDN pricing. What you need is competition combined with privatisation. The great virtue of privatisation, as those on that side well know because they have been down this path on a number of occasions, is that there is virtually nothing left in the cupboard when it comes to privatisation. The reason you did it and the reason we want to do it is that it forces efficiencies on the company. In other words, at the moment there is simply no accountability. You have heard me say this before: if you have lines per employee of 140 and the comparison with the American Bell operating company is 280 to 300 and New Zealand close to 300—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a stupid comparison.

—It is not stupid, Bob. Perhaps you ought to have a good look at US West, which covers 14 states of the United States, has very similar geographic dispersity and population density and is much more efficient than Telstra. Telstra knows that. Their operating cost per employee, their lines per employee, their revenue per employee are well off the mark—30 per cent below OECD standards in a number of instances. If you do not believe in productivity and efficiency, then you simply do not believe in lower telephone charges and you do not believe in higher quality of service. That is why it was very silly of Senator Bourne to somehow suggest the other day that, because the Netherlands and Belgium have temporarily overtaken Australia on the NUS survey as having the highest local call charges in the world, that is some sort of vindication of current policies.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that Telstra itself acknowledges it has to lift its game. It is going to be exposed to much greater competition in the very near future with Optus coming into the local calls market. It is going to have full and open competition from 1 July next year and it will mean that a lot of very heavy hitters will be coming into this business. When you have standards of inefficiency that bedevil Telstra at the present time, it is going to make it very difficult for them to compete. That BZW survey, which estimated Telstra's value at $27.6 billion, is obviously proceeding on a number of assumptions, all of which, of course, depend crucially upon Telstra delivering the goods.

I think you would find that BZW assumes that Telstra will in fact achieve its 30 per cent reduction in unit costs over the next two years. It is a big ask. They have not been able to do that in recent times. As you would know, their work force went from 66,000 to 73,000 in the last financial year and, since January this year, another 3,500 to 4,000. You simply cannot achieve productivity on that basis when all the other telcos in the Western world have been reducing staff levels, sometimes in the order of 10 to 15 per cent, even though they might have started privatisation a decade ago. You can bury your heads in the sand on this. If you want a second class outfit, you are going the right way about it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —On the matter of your continued assertion of the link between privatisation and efficiency, and you brought in productivity, did you notice that the Business Council has reported Australia Post—still, thank goodness, publicly owned—actually has the fourth highest Australian company profit growth over the past five years, productivity improving at twice the national average and a AAA credit rating, shared by only eight other Australian businesses? So we have Telstra—a 65 per cent predicted increase in profitability—and these excellent indicators from Australia Post. They are both publicly owned and within your portfolio. Where is the evidence of your mantra that the private sector always does everything more efficiently?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Only you could put up a straw person to that effect. We have never suggested that only the private sector can do everything more efficiently. The fact is that there are certain institutional structures which make it much more likely than not that you will get efficiencies into the system.
—Where is the evidence?

—Where is the evidence? I know you want to say that we are the only country out of step, that everyone else is wrong except us. The fact is that every other country in the world that has gone for competition in telecommunications has at the same time accompanied that with a commitment to privatisation. The reason they do it is because once you get a bottom line, once you get a price on the share market, you have a daily indication of whether consumers and investors support that company.

ANSWER.PARA: If they do not like it, the price goes south, people bail out and you are left stark naked, and that is the reason they do it. That is the only way you can get true accountability. For the first time you then have people going along and asking the hard questions at annual meetings. You have people testing why it is that they hold certain assets and why they are not prepared to make the decisions that should have been made many years ago. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Attorney‐General. During the election campaign you, as shadow Attorney‐General, promised to save $4.5 million over three years from Auscript by allegedly reducing the parliamentary appropriation to Auscript. Given that Auscript did not receive any parliamentary appropriation in the 1995‐96 financial year and that the forward estimates contained in the last budget do not provide for any parliamentary appropriation to Auscript for the 1996‐97 financial year, how do you propose to make the alleged saving?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator for his question. Without wishing to be too harsh and ungenerous, I can see why they put you third on your Senate ticket. If you had read all the information—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the answer?
—No, that is not the answer. But, if you want to interrupt and want me to stop there, I will stop. If you want a better answer and you will button up for a minute, you will get it.
—Order! I suggest you come to the answer, minister.

—I was trying to, but I was constantly baited by interjections from the senator who asked the question—not from the rest of the riff‐raff here but from the fellow who asked the question. If you go through those documents prior to the election, you will see that there are a number of ways that you can make savings. You can make them by cutting appropriations and you can make them by raising revenue.

ANSWER.PARA: Savings in the Attorney‐General's portfolio are no longer my responsibility. I just point out that to you. Do not assume for one minute that you can make savings only by cutting money. You can make them by collecting money as well, as your government well knows—the government that said that it would not introduce taxes, and then did. That is my initial answer to you. I further add that that primary responsibility is now with the Attorney‐General, Daryl Williams, and I feel perfectly confident that, when he is ready to say what he will do vis‐a‐vis the budget, he will. I strongly suspect—just to clue you up in case you haven't cottoned on—that that will be on budget night.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, minister. You referred to what you said in documents in the election campaign. I have a document here which purports to be a copy of your election policy. It very clearly says that savings of the magnitude that I mentioned are planned for that department. In fact, I also have a copy of a document here from the head of the department which says `the reduction involved in budget funding for Auscript was implemented some time ago and nothing further is planned in this regard'. It seems to be quite clear to me that you were in error when you made those statements. Can you further enlighten the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I can spell it out any more clearly than I already have. Let me run it past you again, though, and see whether the second time around you plug in. Maybe there is a second chance, even for someone like you. The point I made was that you can make savings either by cutting expenditure in an area—limiting an appropriation—or by collecting money. By collecting money you can improve your position, including in the sense of savings. If you have not got a grip on that, there are a number of people here who would be happy to give you a longer lecture on it—but I am not going to waste the Senate's time now.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In relation to the requirement that states report by June 1996 on their progress in implementing competition policy reform, and the requirement that all state and territory governments present proposals for public interest tests and community service obligations to be applied under competition policy as announced by then Assistant Treasurer George Gear on 6 June 1995, what procedure has the new government put in place to monitor progress; who is handling it; and how is progress in implementation to be assessed, especially in regard to public interest and community service proposals?

—The matter is being handled by the Treasurer, Mr Costello, and the procedures that are being adopted—in particular the tests that are to be applied to determine public interest and community service proposals—will be the subject of announcement in the not too distant future. It is currently being considered by the new government. In the meantime, the government is strongly committed to fostering competition in markets for goods and services. The government will maintain the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to guard against anticompetitive conduct and will also promote compliance with the competition principles agreement, including in the areas of prices oversight, competitive neutrality, structural reform of public monopolies, legislation review and access to infrastructure facilities. The government will be looking for the states and territories to make satisfactory progress with the implementation of national competition policy and related reforms.

—I think that is what we were all afraid of—process by announcement. What means have been taken to ensure that proposals for public interest provisions and community service obligations are developed through broad consultation with the public and the community; that progress has been made in holding fora or obtaining public input into these questions; and that the states take such basic measures as consultation with the public?
—It may well include public consultation. I will certainly pass on to Mr Costello Senator Dee Margetts's view that it should.
—My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs.
—That is four in a row over there.

—Order! There has been an agreement between the parties that we would continue with the old system of question allocation until an arrangement has been made. That is being done. If you want to check it, come around to my office afterwards.

—I remind you, Minister, that in your first public statements as minister you said that the Prime Minister had selected you for the Aboriginal affairs portfolio to concentrate on improving the health and health services of Aboriginal people. I also draw your attention to public statements on 10 April this year by the Australian Medical Association, calling for a national forum on Aboriginal health to plan the way ahead and to dispel harmful myths about funding levels. Of course, this was on the same day as you and the Prime Minister announced new accountability measures for ATSIC. Can you inform the Senate whether you have given any consideration to the call by the Australian Medical Association for the forum—and, if not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much for the question. It is a very serious matter, as you are aware, and I have given some consideration to it. I have discussed with the Australian Medical Association as to how we should progress it, and I have received from them a paper in this regard. The actual structure of any summit has not been discussed, but I have liaised with them and both spoken with the federal president and received, as I say, a copy from them.

ANSWER.PARA: I have also discussed with the state health minister in Queensland, Mr Mike Horan, a meeting between himself, myself and the federal health minister, so that we can go around the communities in Queensland. I believe that there is an opportunity for the first time—this could have been done in the 13 years that you were in government, but it did not occur—for the federal health minister, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and the state health minister to work towards producing a template which can be followed in the other states, because Queensland is my own home state and I have been around those communities previously.

So I think the emphasis should be on health outcome. When you consider that malnutrition in children under the age of five still exists in Port Keats in the Northern Territory, for example, after 13 years, as I said the other day, the opposition should hang their heads in shame in regard to the outcome of what has occurred. We still have those 120 communities without adequate water supply and another 200 without adequate sewerage.

I am also pleased to announce that I have been liaising with the Australasian College of Surgeons—the group that you have just been denigrating on that side—and they have got together a group of surgeons who are willing to go out and work for nothing in Aboriginal communities. They are going to allow surgeons in the Northern Territory, in particular, to go to remote communities and replace them.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not news.
—It is perfectly new, Senator Collins. You would not be aware of it. Your government knocked them back for funding. They asked for funding from your minister, and he knocked them back.

ANSWER.PARA: Now the Australasian College of Surgeons has a group of up to 50 surgeons who are prepared to go to remote communities or relieve surgeons to go to remote communities—and I am investigating that so it can be progressed. That comes out of the fact that I am a fellow of that college. So they are going to relieve surgeons to go out there—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are they going to conduct surgery?
—Aren't you aware, Senator Collins, of the desperate need for ear, nose and throat surgeons, for example, in remote communities?
—Yes, I am.
—You are. Well, why didn't you do anything about it over the last 13 years? You have been a minister; you did nothing about it, Senator Collins.
—Order! Senator Herron, address yourself through the chair, please; and, Senator Collins, I would ask you not to interject.

—Mr President, through you, I like Senator Collins interjecting because it gives me great pleasure to tell him of his neglect and what his government neglected over that period of time. They had every opportunity—and what did they do? They did nothing.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I also note the concern you express that Aboriginal infant mortality rates are two to three times those of the non-Aboriginal population and the life expectancy rates are 16 to 19 per cent worse for the indigenous population. In this respect, and given your claimed emphasis on health outcomes, can I ask what benchmarks you have set against which you can be judged in 12 months time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —You made a mistake in your supplementary question. You said 16 to 19 per cent; it was actually 16 to 19 years difference. Would you care to correct that in your question?
—What is the percentage?
—It is 16 to 19 years difference in life expectancy, Senator. You ought to get your questions right. If you cannot get your questions right, how do you expect me to answer them accurately for you?
—Answer the question.

—Well, she did not get the question right. Am I going to be put out of order like you, Senator Crowley, as when Senator Campbell said I should be put out of order because I did not ask the right question?

ANSWER.PARA: The fact of the matter is that the difficulty with benchmarks in the Aboriginal community is that discrete surveys have been done and, as Senator Collins is well aware, every community is different. You might have a different rheumatic fever rate in one area and a different otitis media incidence in another area so that, overall, it is very difficult to obtain those percentages. The first thing we are doing is surveying it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, can you advise the Senate of the outcome of last week's negotiations between Australia, New Zealand and Japan on the conservation of the southern bluefin tuna; and, in the light of these negotiations, are you able to advise the Senate of this government's commitment to the sustainable management of Australian fisheries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would particularly like to thank Senator Ferguson for that question because I know of the consuming interest that he has had—and not just Senator Ferguson, but also other coalition senators from Tasmania, Western Australia and South Australia, particularly Senator Calvert from Hobart who has made a lot of representations to me on this issue.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased to tell the Senate that Australia, Japan and New Zealand have agreed on this year's global catch quota for southern bluefin tuna. The Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna, which is made up of those three countries, set the global quota at 11,750 tonnes, with national allocations of 5,265 to Australia, 6,065 to Japan and 420 to New Zealand, the same levels as last year. The negotiations were particularly difficult and protracted because the scientific experts in Australia disagreed quite significantly with the scientific experts in Japan. The Japanese had proposed to increase the annual catch, in fact, by 6,000 tonnes.

Australia did not support this proposal, neither did New Zealand. The outcome of the negotiations vindicates the determination to pursue responsible and sustainable international fisheries management. I think it is to the credit of all parties, considering the acrimony that went on during the negotiations, that a satisfactory outcome has been achieved.

The commission agreed on a substantial program of collaborative scientific work to reduce uncertainties in our knowledge of the tuna stock. It set down objectives and principles for evaluating whether experimental fishing could in the future provide for more responsive decision making in the fishery.

The three countries agreed that any experimental fishing contemplated in the future must not jeopardise the recovery of the stock to the 1980 level by the year 2020. Setting a target recovery date is a major leap forward for the commission. It recognises that tuna stocks will still take years to recover from the overfishing of previous decades. The results of the negotiations highlight this government's commitment to responsible fisheries management. I would like to particularly compliment officers of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy who, in collaboration and much consultation with me—

TALK.START.PARA: —They were well led.

—Thank you, Senator Cook, they were well led—in their successful conclusion of these difficult negotiations. We believe that the Commonwealth has a leadership role to play in protecting our marine environment and ensuring that our marine resources are harvested in an efficient and sustainable way. We recognise this responsibility in our environment policy. We are determined, in particular, to implement our coasts and clean seas initiative which will provide $100 million towards efforts to improve the quality of our coastal and marine environment.

ANSWER.PARA: Our ability to implement this vital aspect of our policy depends upon the partial privatisation of Telstra. It will be an absolute disaster for the environment if the Labor Party and the minor parties in this place continue their opposition to that sale. The Labor Party's privatisation policy, of course, is totally incoherent. Those opposite recognised the importance of privatisation when they were in government. They sold the Commonwealth Bank, although they lied about how much they planned to sell. They also sold Qantas.

The Labor Party sold them simply to get money, not for a specific purpose such as this. Now that the Labor Party is in opposition, it is opposing privatisation on the most specious of grounds imaginable. Let me tell opposition senators that if they oppose the privatisation of Telstra and the creation of the natural heritage trust they will be remembered as the party that talked about the environment but bailed out when it had the chance to support the most important capital investment in the environment in the last 50 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Short representing the Minister for Finance. Does the government stand by its election commitments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —Through you, Mr President, I will tell Senator Cook what the government stands for. The government stands committed to repairing the absolute fiscal vandalism that it inherited from the previous government. The government stands committed to balancing the books of this nation and to restoring some fiscal responsibility into the affairs of this nation so that people will again have the integrity of government restored to them. —Order! I made that point on a number of occasions. If you like, I can show you examples. I ask the minister to come to the point of the answer.

—I respect your ruling, Mr President, but I cannot make it any clearer either to yourself, with respect, or to the opposition that the fundamental election commitment that the coalition gave to the Australian people was to repair the damage that had been done by the former Labor government to the finances of Australia and to the hope, confidence and future of all Australians. We are deeply committed to that cause, as we were during the election campaign. During the life of this parliament, in the next budget and on all other appropriate occasions, we will be meeting that range of commitments to the Australian people. We will not be deceiving the Australian people; we will not be lying to the Australian people in the way that our predecessors did. We will not tell all age pensioners that they will be removed from the tax system by 1995 and then do nothing about it.

ANSWER.PARA: We will not tell the Australian people that we are going to have a major reduction in unemployment only to preside over policies and to introduce policies that cause unemployment to rise massively. We are not going to tell the Australian people that we will enshrine tax cuts in law and then break our promise to the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The one‐minute light has come on and the question was `Does the government stand by its election commitments?' We have still not got an answer to that question. Senator Short cannot continue to go on avoiding that question. Will he now tell us yes or no—or, in words of one sentence, whether the government intends to meet its election commitments or not. It is a simple question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not quite follow, but it has always been the case that it is impossible to follow the logic of any question that Senator Cook attempts to ask. Let me try and unravel a little of it. First of all, I have answered, in quite categorical terms, that we will be meeting the commitments that we gave to the Australian people to restore integrity and confidence in government, to restore the books back into balance and to give people an opportunity, through policies for the future.

ANSWER.PARA: Apart from those basic commitments to which I have already alluded, two of the major commitments we made during the election campaign were to introduce into this country industrial laws that produced hope for the future of the Australian work force and to sell one-third of Telstra. I hope very much that the opposition will allow us to meet those commitments. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston. My question relates to the universal service obligation on telecommunication carriers. Under the powers of the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill 1996 presented last week, carriers have a means of escape from the universal service obligations if those obligations are deemed to be inefficient or uneconomic. Doesn't this make nonsense of the government's assurances, both before and after the election, that Australians in regional areas will not be worse off if Telstra is privatised?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —When I saw the release from the Leader of the Australian Democrats last Thursday, I could not believe my eyes. We were told that the Democrats were proposing to release a leaflet to all householders—which, presumably, would be at taxpayers' expense—and that they had not yet received a copy of the bill. In other words, they had made up their mind to go out and tell the Australian public what was wrong with this bill before they had read it. What the leaflet said was this, amongst other things:

ANSWER.PARA: Would you trust a private company to provide a guaranteed level of access to all Australians if it affected their profits?

That deals with the universal service obligation. Clearly it was written before you had seen the bill, so there you were trotting out a blind prejudice. You well know that it is not simply a matter of leaving it to a private company to do the right thing. The legislation very specifically requires it, and we said that in our pre-election commitments. We have said it ever since. You ought to have known that from the outset.

What Senator Woodley also ought to know, if he had read the legislation, is that in section 287 of the Telecommunications Act there is a very specific outlining of the universal service obligation. The act goes on to spell out the formula that is required to fund that through the universal service levy. What the bill does is reaffirm that commitment but, at the same time, it leaves in the existing Telecommunications Act the requirement for the universal service obligation to be implemented.

In other words, there can be no possible way in which you can water that down. You would need to change two acts of parliament. I presume you are not about to do that. I find it extraordinary. I do not know whether you have been having too many dinners with Senator Kim Carr or whether you are simply getting your advice from the mad left of the union movement who are opposed to these sorts of things.
What Senator Kernot also says in the press release she put out the following day—in other words, compounding the felony—is:
A ministerial declaration already sets out, as a condition of a telecommunications licence, the minimum response times on the provision of services.

The fact is that all that is required under a ministerial direction is for Telstra to provide information or status reports on the extent to which they are complying or measuring up with certain standards that they, themselves, set in their corporate plan.

BREAK.PARA: In other words, there is no ministerial direction requiring a minimum standard. That is why we are putting it in legislation. The only place you would find a minimum requirement on the part of Telstra is on page 14 of the White Pages, and we do not regard that as good enough. That is why we want to legislate. The universal service obligation is absolutely essential to this legislation. It is provided for in spades. We have reaffirmed an existing legislative requirement. In other words, it is in there twice—and you have the cheek to get out there and mislead the Australian public, play to the fear and ignorance, in other words, the lowest common denominator party. Why don't you rename your slogan `Lowering the standards'? You obviously are not interested in ensuring that the public knows what it is all about.

You say, for example, `While the coalition says foreign ownership will be limited to 35 per cent, can you believe them?'—again as if you have to take our word for it. It is in the legislation. That is why you have an act of parliament—to provide these safeguards. We want it all done by legislation. You want to pretend to the Australian public that it is a matter of choice. It simply is not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Perhaps if you are going to change names you ought to change your bill to `Telstra (Destruction of Public Ownership) Bill'. However, Senator Alston, I did not get my question either from the Labor left or even from Senator Kernot's leaflet; I got it straight from your legislation. The universal service obligation in your legislation has the escape clause in it that if the universal service obligations do not meet the test of efficiency or economics then they will be fallen from. So there is the escape clause. It is in your legislation. Could you please explain to me how you will be able to maintain those obligations?

—I have made it abundantly clear that part C of schedule 1 reaffirms in identical terms the requirements of section 287. So it is crystal clear that we are not wanting to water down any existing universal service obligation. Indeed, if you looked at international experience—
—It is not adding anything to it.

—Have you finished? If you looked at international experience you would find that the universal service obligation is borrowed identically from the American experience. They invented the universal service fund, the universal service levy. In other words, they provided cross-subsidies to rural and remote areas where services would otherwise be uneconomic. They have never had public ownership of telecommunications carriers. Senator Woodley's ideological preferences are clearly showing when he thinks that any dilution of government ownership constitutes a destruction of government ownership. It certainly constitutes a watering down, but it does it very much in the public interest. That is why you have a legislative regime. You simply do not leave it to the market or to the company. We will put it into legislation. That is where it will stay. (Time expired)
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, the opposition for its part made very clear that we believed that not only should the issue of proposed sessional orders for the Senate be discussed, but an important aspect of the Senate procedures, namely the allocation of questions in question time, also should be subject to the same process of informal discussion. TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

—That will remain to be seen, because I have—

That is agreed by all of the parties. I can do no more than take their instructions. It is impossible to allocate questions in an acceptable way unless the parties agree. —Mr President, on a point of order: I draw to the Senate's attention a clear understanding under the standing orders that whenever Mr or Madam President stands the Senate will hear the President in silence. It would seem that, if you do not have agreement, then you ought to do it either strictly pro rata or by some method that approaches that which involves going from one side of the chamber to the other. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron), to a question without notice asked by Senator Bob Collins today, relating to ministerial guidelines and Senator Herron practising as a surgeon.
The reason I asked Senator Herron the question I did today was to draw attention to two things, but in particular the guide that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) issued on ministerial responsibility.

Just to respond to Senator Herron's interjections, it was not the opposition that put up this particular proposition. It was the Prime Minister, with a great deal of chest thumping and spotlights, who put this out as the new government that was going to sweep clean with a new broom and have this super‐duper set of guidelines for their ministers, parliamentary secretaries and so on to adhere to.

You are not the only one with problems, Senator Herron, which is what I wanted the opportunity of pointing out today. The Prime Minister has to concede either these ministerial guidelines that he put out with great pomp and circumstance are unworkable, or he has to have a number of ministers make some, to quote the Prime Minister, `significant personal sacrifices'.
Clearly, Senator Herron has not bothered to read these guidelines or if he has he has not understood them because there is nothing in here about profit or loss. In the preamble it states:
Along with the privilege of serving as a minister . . . there is some personal sacrifice in terms of the time and energy—
not money—
that must be devoted to official duties . . .
The guidelines go on to state:
Ministers . . . must not engage in any professional practice or in the daily work of any business.
It cannot be much more explicit than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the lot of it.
—I have read the lot of it, Senator, but you have not bothered to. There is one paragraph that intrigues me and it is also very explicit. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Ministers are required to divest themselves of all shares and similar interests in any company or business involved in the area of their portfolio responsibilities. The transfer of interests to a family member or to a nominee or trust is not an acceptable form of divestment.

In other words, the blind trust arrangement that Malcolm Fraser operated when he was Prime Minister is no longer suitable for these squeaky cleaners. Where does this explicit paragraph leave the federal Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson)? I would say that, referring to the Prime Minister's guidelines, it means his having to either resign as a minister or make a very considerable personal sacrifice in selling his considerable primary industry interests.

I will specifically indicate why this is a problem. It is a problem because the primary industry minister made a controversial ministerial decision a couple of weeks ago that potentially affects his bank balances. That was the decision he made to revoke, to the great chagrin of the beef industry in Australia, the trials that were set up under the previous government relating to the importation of grain.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful!
—Yes.
—Is he a grain grower?

—He certainly is a grain grower and a significant one. They are going to not only suspend the trials but also explicitly rule out having any future trials. Why is this a problem? I will tell you why. At the height of the drought and when domestic grain supplies were absolutely at crisis point the price went through the roof, putting a lot of lot feeders out of business. The price went beyond $300 a tonne. It was exacerbated by the fact that a lot of grain growers around Australia, not unreasonably, were withdrawing grain because it was going up at the rate of $10 and $20 a tonne per week. Senator Crane and Senator Panizza know this. It went right through the roof. You cannot blame the grain growers for doing that when they were in difficult circumstances, but that is what was happening.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a demonstrable fact that, within two weeks of the then government announcing that it was going for the first time in Australian history to permit the importation of the grain, the price went down. Tens of dollars got washed off that price within a fortnight. That was measured by ABARE. I am happy to table the graphs that ABARE produced demonstrating this fact. That was the very reason the government announced this measure.

What Mr Anderson has done, at the behest of his fellow grain growers—and this has caused a great public outcry among the very valuable lot feeding industry in Australia—is not only close down the trial and withdraw the Commonwealth support that the former government provided but also announce, to my astonishment, that he is not going to allow any future trials. He has stated:
He ruled out any new trials suggesting that live stock feeders . . . during any future domestic shortage.

I am not suggesting for one minute that Mr Anderson has deliberately done that in order to increase the price he might get for his grain, but the fact is that it will have that effect. As the former primary industry minister, I often reflected and discussed with my staff how Mr Anderson, as a minister and with his significant holdings in primary industry, would have handled a number of submissions that I took into cabinet because they would have directly affected his income as a producer. There is no question that making it difficult to import grain is going to improve his bank balance. He has to resign as a minister, sell his farm or change the guidelines. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —There seems to have been a lot of heat generated in this regard. Senator Collins did not say, when referring to those guidelines, that ministers were asked to respond to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) by 27 May. I think that should be made clear. I made an appointment to see the Prime Minister in this regard last Tuesday.

—Yes, I did, but it was overrun by the disaster in Tasmania. If you recall, he went down to Tasmania the following day. I have another appointment to see him. We are to respond to the guidelines by 27 May. I have a significant decision to make in this regard, but the reality is that I rather enjoy saving lives. It is a hobby for me in that I do not make any money out of it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins would not be aware that the only holiday I have had since coming into parliament was my two months in Rwanda. I enjoyed working there. I regard surgery as a hobby. There are no funds. I am happy to see patients on a Sunday afternoon if that is what you require of me. I have been operating on Saturdays and Sundays and seeing patients on Saturdays and Sundays. That is the love that I have for my profession. You would not understand that. The sum of you have all been trade union officials or employees. None of you have been in an occupation of any significance. It is something that I enjoy.

At the end of day, I am not taking a stand in this regard particularly for myself. In essence surgery is a skill that requires re‐accreditation every year. The Royal Australasian College of Surgeons requires its members to be re‐accredited every year. You have to fulfil those re‐accreditation requirements to be able to operate. TALK.START.PARA: —If any one of us had done this you would have screamed your heads off.

I think I need to give you an explanation of my motivation. It is something that I enjoy doing. You will be interested to know that I have no other hobbies. My hobby is surgery. My hobby is looking after sick people. I get emotional satisfaction from my hobby. I pay to do it. I do it in my spare time.
—Get the Prime Minister to change the guidelines.

—Are you saying, Senator Collins, that one's spare time should be spent totally in the pursuit of politics? That is what you are saying. If that is your requirement, then I reject it. Ultimately, it is the Prime Minister's decision, and I will accept the Prime Minister's decision. I have said that clearly. I said that on the program yesterday. The Prime Minister is the boss, and I will accept his decision.

SPEECH.PARA: Ultimately, I can do more for the Aboriginal people of this country—more than you did, Senator Collins, in the time you were in government—as a minister. I am happy to stay as the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, because the health outcomes in that regard are probably more important.

I realise that I am reaching the end of my surgical career because of the efflux of time, even though I still feel quite vigorous. Now he is saying, `If he tells me to give up my hobby—my surgeon's profession—I will give it up.'

PARA.EMPHASIS: Vietnamese Asylum Seekers in CPA (Comprehensive Plan of Action) Camps

SPEECH.PARA: a. The Coalition government has stated its policy on forced repatriation of Vietnamese asylum seekers on several occasions, including in a letter dated 1 March 1996 to the Vietnamese Australian community. This policy provides that a Coalition government would not support the use of forced repatriation unless some conditions are satisfied, these conditions being:
1. All avenues of voluntary repatriation have been exhausted.
2. The Coalition is convinced that the screening decisions have been made free from corruption.
3. The asylum seeker has been approved for repatriation by Vietnamese authorities.
4. The asylum seeker does not at the time of planned repatriation have a valid application for "mandate" consideration lodged with the UNHCR.
5. The asylum seeker does not at the time of planned repatriation have a valid application lodged with the Australian government for migration to Australia under the Preferential Family category.
6. The asylum seeker does not have immediate family members (spouse and dependent children) remaining in the camp from which he or she is to be deported.

b. The Coalition government has announced that immediate family members (spouses and dependent children) of people who enter Australia under a refugee or humanitarian program should have their migration application to Australia processed and they should be allowed to migrate to Australia without having to return to Vietnam first. Since late 1995, it has made representations to UNHCR and the then Labor Federal government to seek to achieve the above;

c. In February 1996 UNHCR used its funds, to which Australia contributed, to finance a forced repatriation operation in the Philippines (documents giving evidence to support this, in the form of confidential government and UNHCR documents, are circulated to all honourable Parliamentarians and the media in April 1996);

d. The Coalition government has accepted the assurances on UNHCR that there remains no refugee among the asylum seekers. This acceptance has been made despite UNHCR itself, since it emphasized this assurance in August 1995, having acknowledged dozens of refugees who previously had been denied refugee status, and despite the fact that the internal investigation—upon which UNHCR based its assurance—was not independently conducted or supervised by non‐UNHCR personnel.
Your petitioners therefore hereby request that the Senate ask the Australian government to:

a. Inform the governments of the first asylum countries of its policy above and make urgent representations to discuss this policy with these governments. In particular, the Australian government should take measures as part of these representations to ensure that no forced repatriation should apply to people who satisfy conditions 3 to 6 above;

b. Process, or expedite its processing of, immediate family members of people who enter Australia under a refugee or humanitarian program, to allow them to migrate to Australia without having to return to Vietnam first. As part of this, the Australian government should request the host governments for access to the relevant asylum seeker for processing, and for

permission to emigrate directly from such countries. We note that the Hong Kong government has given such permission, the Philippines government—having decided not to use forced repatriation—will in all likelihood not refuse such requests;

c. Require UNHCR to assure the government that it will not in future once again use funds contributed by Australia in any forced repatriation, and condition future funding to UNHCR on the performance of such assurances;

d. Conduct an independent investigation into whether UNHCR conducted its role under the CPA in a proper manner, and in accordance with its charter of refugee protection. As part of such investigation, the government should give assurances to former asylum seekers who are now in Australia to come forward as witnesses with full confidentiality and protection, and the investigation should also accept evidence from former asylum seekers who have returned to Vietnam or who have moved to another country.

The statement read as follows—
CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1996
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE 1996 WINTER SITTINGS

In the 1995 Winter Sittings, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Act 1995 (Act No. 87 of l995)(the CELA Act) was passed by the Parliament. The CELA Act made substantial amendments to the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme to tighten the eligibility criteria for rebates of customs and excise duty paid on purchases of diesel fuel.

In the course of the Senate debate on the CELA Act, 80 amendments were successfully moved to the CELA Bill as introduced. In the course of translating those amendments into a final Royal Assent Bill, several substantive problems with the commencement and the application and savings provisions were created which were acknowledged as contrary to the expressed intention of the Senate.

The application and savings provisions problems arose because modifications were not made to these provisions to take account of amendments made by the then Opposition and Greens, in particular relating to the law as it applied to quarrying and sand mining prior to 1 July 1995. Also, consequential amendments were not made to the commencement provisions even though it was agreed that particular amendments would commence at particular times. Several minor transcription errors in the CELA Act were also identified.

On 29 August 1995, the then Government introduced the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 (the Bill) into the Senate. The purpose of the Bill was to amend the CELA Act to correct the transcription errors the problems with the commencement and the applications and savings provisions. However, the Bill lapsed upon the prorogation of Parliament on 29 January 1996.

The need to correct the problems with the application provisions and restore the Senate's intention still exists, particularly in relation to the law applicable to mining for minerals. The CELA Act removed the eligibility for diesel fuel rebate used in the extraction of certain materials, including sand, with effect from 1 July 1995 only. Any existing rebate applications, or any matters before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) or the courts, that relate to the use of diesel fuel in mining operations prior to 1 July 1995 were intended to be decided in accordance with the law as it existed prior to 1 July 1995.

The CELA Act as passed did not give effect to this intention and without the corrections to the CELA Act proposed in the Bill, these applications will be governed by the amended law. The effect of the Bill is to allow those companies which had lodged applications before 1 July 1995 to have them considered on the basis of the law as it existed prior to 1 July 1995, thereby restoring the original intention of the CELA Act. Should such applications be successful, in excess of S90 million in diesel fuel rebate would be payable and there are approximately 300 such applications awaiting determination in the AAT.
The applications before the AAT and the courts are currently listed for hearing in the next four months. It is for this reason that the corrections proposed by the Bill have an urgent commencement.

The speech read as follows—
The purpose of this bill is to amend the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Act 1995 (Act No. 87 of 1995) (the CELA Act).

The CELA Act made substantial amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901 relating to the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme, to tighten the eligibility criteria for rebates of customs and excise duty paid on purchases of diesel fuel.

In the course of the Senate debate on the CELA Act on 29 and 30 June 1995, 80 amendments were successfully moved to the CELA Bill as introduced. In the course of translating those amendments into a final Royal Assent bill, several substantive problems with the commencement and the application and savings provisions were created which were acknowledged as contrary to the expressed intention of the Senate.

The application and savings provisions problems arose because modifications were not made to these provisions to take account of amendments made by the then Opposition and Greens, in particular relating to the law as it applied to quarrying and sand mining prior to 1 July 1995. Also, consequential amendments were not made to the commencement provisions even though it was agreed that particular amendments would commence at particular times. Several minor transcription errors in the CELA Act were also identified.

On 29 August 1995, the then government introduced the Customs and Excise Legislation Amend ment Bill (No. 2) 1995 into the Senate. The purpose of that bill was to amend the CELA Act to correct the transcription errors and the problems with the commencement and the application and savings provisions. However, the bill lapsed upon the prorogation of Parliament on 29 January 1996.

With the exception of one minor addition which I will discuss shortly, this bill is in substantially the same form as the 29 August 1995 bill and is being pursued because the need to correct the problems with the application provisions and restore the Senate's intention still exists, particularly in relation to the law applicable to mining for minerals. The CELA Act amended the definition of minerals by excluding certain materials, with effect from 1 July 1995 only. Any existing rebate applications, or any matters before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) or the courts, that relate to the use of diesel fuel in mining operations prior to 1 July 1995 were intended to be decided in accordance with the law as it existed prior to 1 July 1995.

The CELA Act as passed did not give effect to this intention and without the corrections to the CELA Act proposed in this bill, these applications will be governed by the amended law. The principal effect of the bill is to allow those companies which had lodged applications before 1 July 1995 to have them considered on the basis of the law as it existed prior to 1 July 1995, thereby restoring the original intention of the CELA Act.
Introduction and passage of this bill will make those essential technical amendments.

The bill also makes one minor addition to the CELA Act to restore Diesel Fuel Rebate eligibility for the extraction of limestone for use in the de‐acidification of soil in agriculture, post 1 July 1995.
FINANCIAL IMPACT STATEMENT
The technical "correction" amendments proposed in this bill have no additional financial impact to the CELA Act.

The amendment in this bill concerning the restoration of Diesel Fuel Rebate eligibility for the extraction of limestone for use in soil de‐acidification in agriculture is expected to involve an additional cost to revenue of about $620,000 a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much, Mr Acting Deputy President.

SPEECH.PARA: This particular bill, the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1996, is a consolidated version of the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1995 which was introduced by the Labor government in 1995 during the life of the last parliament. It incorporates a number of amendments that, as the previous environment minister, I moved on behalf of the then government on 30 November last year. I can say—and this probably will not come as a great surprise to you, Mr Acting Deputy President—that the opposition is going to support this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —We supported it last time.
