SPEECH.PARA: The major reason for amending the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1989 was and is still our much needed requirement to remedy the discrepancy between Australia's international obligations and our domestic legislation. The principle act's definition of `hazardous waste' does not cover material sent for recovery operations—that is, for reclamation of metals or recovery of other useful materials. The Basel convention was drafted to cover both kinds of processes—that is, both final disposal and recovery operations. Both kinds of processes are included in the convention definitions under the single term `disposal'.

The bill also provides for the establishment of a technical group of scientific and technical experts to advise the minister on what is and is not a hazardous waste under the bill's definition. The technical group will provide the government with the capability of issuing clear guidance on definitional issues.

I think one of the strengths of the bill—and I did refer to this at some length when I introduced this bill during the life of the last parliament—was the fact that its development depended on an extensive consultation process that involved a whole range of interest groups and that was indeed, I think, a very useful exercise. I also think it has meant that the bill itself has been widely supported. I refer Senator Hill particularly to the outstanding second reading speech that I made at great length in 1995 on this particular matter. I think it probably does not behove me well—

TALK.START.PARA: —To quote yourself.
—to quote myself at extraordinary length. I am not like you—
—A few select quotes.

—Not even a few selective quotes, Senator Hill. The wisdom of my remarks stand the test of time. You are very welcome to read them. I am sure you can read all those comments and I am sure you will be able to learn a great deal about this issue which, I do recall, in another life you knew very little about at all. No doubt it would be a very useful tutorial for you as the new environment minister to closely examine those remarks that I made.
—I tried to help you get it through on the last say.

—I am glad Senator Hill raised the issue of the last day of parliament because it was very unfortunate that there was such a very disruptive exercise from the opposition at that time in relation to seeing the passage of this bill. That was not only a disappointment to me as the then environment minister, and the government at that time, but to many other Australians who have a genuine interest in these areas. It is just another conversion that good old Senator Hill had in the corridors of the executive wing.

SPEECH.PARA: It is great to see that Senator Hill has changed his view on these matters and that he has done such another exciting and substantial U‐turn in relation to his approach to these issues. I refer Senator Hill to the very persuasive arguments I mounted at that time and indicate clearly that the opposition will be supporting the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chamarette would certainly like to speak to this bill, but currently she is fogbound on her way into Canberra. As a result, I will speak on this issue concerning an area with which Senator Chamarette and her staff have been concerned over the last several months.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1996 involves the important updating of the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1989 in line with the most recent amendments to the Basel convention on the control of the trans‐boundary movements of hazardous wastes and their disposal. This bill fails to do that in a number of crucial respects.

The global economy is rapidly increasing its consumption of the resources of the natural world. The mentality of consumption and the obsession with the new coupled with the highly synthetic basis of 20th century industry and lifestyle are creating enormous amounts of waste. Many of them are completely alien to the natural environment. Little is being done to find ecologically responsible methods of dealing with this waste.

According to the United Nations environmental program report in 1990, 300 million to 400 million tonnes, or more, of hazardous waste are generated around the world, 98 per cent of them coming from the OECD countries of which Australia is a member. Currently some 200 million hectares of land per year are lost to agriculture due to toxification by this waste alone.

In six out of 24 OECD countries there are 80,000 contaminated waste sites waiting to be cleaned up. Topsoil, which takes 12,000 years per inch to form, is dying under toxic water leaking from inappropriate waste facilities and leaching landfill. Areas carry more and more pollution from the vaporisation of toxic wastes. Rivers like the Rhine and the Mississippi and oceans and coasts are falling prey by the kilometre. The earth is a finite system. It is not producing convenient black holes for this waste to go into. We are rapidly being overrun by our own garbage.

As hazardous waste production increases and effective methods of dealing with it do not correspondingly increase, the desire for countries to export it increases. If it is not possible to deal with it domestically, the most attractive response from mass consumption countries is to get it out of sight. In many cases this means ship it out of the country. The trade in hazardous waste has become a booming industry.

The United States Environmental Protection Agency recorded in 1988 that more than 2.2 million tonnes of toxic garbage crosses the world's borders each year as part of this trade. Between 1986 and 1988 more than 3 million tonnes of waste were shipped from the industrialised world to the non‐industrialised world. What the developed countries throw away in this manner is making the world sick. The developed countries do not have the right to blame this on developing countries.

PARA.BREAK: Australia is by no means blameless. We are one of the seven biggest traders in toxic waste of all 24 OECD countries. What is worse, most of these imports are subject to no regu lation or record whatsoever. This is because they are under the guise of recycling. While they may be environmentally sensible on the surface, it is a manifestation of an attempt to use the community's desire for care of the environment to pull the wool over the rest of the community's eyes.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's junk goes overseas to be processed in dangerous and poorly maintained factories to the detriment of the health of the local people. Companies in rich countries are allowed to get rid of highly hazardous waste by dumping it on poorer countries without strict environmental or health regulations.

The Basel convention was drawn up to address these problems. It deals with the international generation, management and disposal of hazardous waste and revolves around four central aims: firstly, that less hazardous waste be produced on a global level; secondly, that where the generation of hazardous or other waste is unavoidable that waste must be disposed of as close as possible to the source of the generation; thirdly, that hazardous waste may be exported when, and only when, the exporting state does not have the capacity to dispose of it in an environmentally sound manner; and fourthly, that exports should go only to countries that are going to deal with them in an environmentally safe manner.

This cannot be guaranteed, for example, if the importing country is not a party to the convention. Such imports should be categorically prohibited. These intentions are not a matter of interpretation but are clearly stated in the act itself.

There is very little in this bill requiring disposal of waste in Australia where we have the capacity to do so. With reference to the second aim of the convention—proximity of disposal—the act at present addresses this to a degree, but it is not enough. Legislative regulation to lower generation of waste is the most logical basis for an act dealing with hazardous waste, and yet this bill includes almost nothing on this topic.

Government is able quite effectively to regulate generation through the Export Control Act. If an industry cannot obtain a permit to so easily export its waste it will inevitably need to produce less. It will also be directed to deal with the processing of its own waste rather than dumping it on other countries. Hence both domestic processing and a proximity of disposal are dealt with together. As the government is not proposing to do this, we propose to include this requirement in the bill.

This is clearly an area where government is able to legislate to reflect the Basel convention. With this bill it has simply—as did the previous government—decided not to do so. The ban decision is quite obviously a reflection of the third stated aim of the convention: it is very important for human rights and environmental concerns.

Importing waste is often a source of income for countries short‐changed by the global economic system. I might say that it is very short‐term income and the country is left with an unmanageable debt burden. The countries involved become dependent on a trade that is literally killing and maiming them. According to the World Bank, since 1984 the net transfers from industrialised to developing countries have been negative. The last thing the world—and particularly Australia—should be doing is legislating to send these countries our toxic waste as well. Perhaps we would benefit from the tragedy that most people in these countries are unaware that they are being bequeathed legacies that will kill and maim them. If they did know, I think that the outrage they would feel and express would strike home to us.

With this bill Australia is exploiting the advantage we already have. To extend the interpretation to the extent that the substances can be classified as `not hazardous waste' is against the letter and the spirit of the convention. It is an extremely dangerous and foolhardy course for any government to take. This clause essentially means that hazardous waste can arrive at the doorstep of other countries, or even Australia, having circumvented the normal safety requirements. Recipients will simply not know what they are receiving.

It is incomprehensible to the Greens (WA) how any government could have conceived of such a downright reckless strategy to enact its opposition to the ban decision. We advise the government in the strongest possible terms to reconsider this clause. We know it was born of a previous government, but that does not mean that it should not be looked at very carefully.

A welcome change to this act in the bill is the alteration of the definition of waste to be in line with the definition used in the convention. The annual report for the operation of the hazardous waste act 1989 states that in 1993 no export permits were granted, yet Australia exported 20,000 kilograms of lead battery waste and a further 20,000 kilograms of waste aluminium cans to Hong Kong in this year. None of it was recorded because the current definition of waste is `anything that has been rejected as worthless by a person who has or had possession of it, whether or not someone else may regard it as having some value'. Goods intended to be recycled are excluded from control under the act.

The definition proposed by this bill is much tighter. Lead battery waste pollutes waterways and discharges lead battery ash into the air if processed in dangerous and poorly maintained incinerators. Many incinerators, especially those in poor countries, contain regressive, substandard technologies that cannot be relied on to dispose of toxic waste to safe levels. Even in the United States in 1994, all hazardous waste incinerators were found to be substandard to United States federal law.

There is no requirement under this act that receiving governments ensure that human rights, health and the environment are taken into consideration in the development of science. When inhaled, lead based pollution has been known to permanently lower the IQs of children. Governments must endorse and legislate for the ban decision coupled with a change to the definition of waste to ensure the sealing of this loophole.
I apologise on behalf of Senator Chamarette that she has not been able to participate in this debate so far, and I look forward to the minister's response to our concerns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —We did deal with this legislation last year and the Democrats will be dealing with it in much the same way this year with some additional amendments. I must say that I, too, am entertained to see a change in the attitude of the previous opposition with regard to the urgency of this matter, but I agree that this is an important piece of legislation at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is and remains an international disgrace because it is not meeting its obligations under the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and their Disposal. I would remind the Senate that the Basel convention was adopted in 1989 and Australia joined in early 1992. While there are over 60 signatories to the convention at the moment, there are some notable exceptions, for example, the United States.

The convention has seen increasingly severe restrictions agreed to internationally to limit the trade in toxic wastes and, in particular, to try to prevent countries of the north, or the developed world, from dumping hazardous wastes on countries of the south, or the less developed world.

In 1993 another convention banned the dumping of industrial and nuclear waste at sea. The International Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter—which is known as the London dumping convention—means that waste dumped at sea now has to be disposed of on land, meaning that poisons will be released onto the soil and into the land environment unless that waste is treated.

I am reminded particularly of the situation with jarosite dumping which continues to this day in Tasmania. I think that is due to a lack of zealous application and imagination by the previous government rather than practical possibilities, because I know that it is possible to do one of two things: either reorganise the method of production of zinc in Tasmania, because it is possible to produce zinc by other processes than the process which requires jarosite; or arrange for its disposal or at least storage on land.

We could comply with the London dumping convention. We have chosen not to. For that we continue in disgrace, thumbing our noses at the requirements of the convention. That is the sort of thing that we continue to follow in our comfortable, First World, developed lifestyles. We retain the luxury of being allowed to protect parts of our environment and ignore other parts and choose to subscribe to conventions or choose not to. We have this luxury. We follow through the nimby type of approach at a national level because we are subjected to the fact that nobody in their right mind wants to have a cesspit or a toxic waste incinerator in their neighbourhood. It is easy for us to follow that at a national level. It becomes easier and cheaper for us to export the waste and to place it out of sight, out of mind.

As stricter regulations have been applied to waste disposal, so the costs have risen and so the quantities and types of hazardous waste have risen. In the United States alone, the amount of hazardous wastes rose from nine million tonnes a year in the early 1970s to 240 million tonnes in 1990. We are still a society which creates exactly what we want and damn the consequences. We worry about them afterwards. In some cases we choose to allow other people to worry about it.

The Democrats maintain the concept that the focus must remain on waste prevention and minimisation, to cut down on the amount and the types of services required to deal with the waste. We do not accept that it is not possible to continue in the way that we are at the moment, where we continue to create greater and greater amounts of waste and to seek to make somebody else responsible. Operators and creators of waste who come to us say that the irresponsible operators get the subsidies to dump cheaply, which makes it unfair and expensive for those good operators who want to meet their community responsibilities. These trends have meant increasing pressure to export the waste. I will quote the coordinator of Greenpeace International's toxic trade prevention project, Mr Jim Pucket, who says that toxic waste, if left to the free market, will follow a path of least resistance. I say: what would you expect? With the decisions of economic rationalists being driven by market demands, of course that is what will happen.

Hazardous waste by-products go to the countries which are most vulnerable and which have the least economic ability to resist them. Cash in return for dumping some slime in a back paddock is hard to refuse. One example is the government of Guinea Bissau, who took over 15 million tonnes of toxic waste for the payment of $600 million. They said they needed the money and that is no doubt the case, and who would refuse a deal that was four times the gross national product of the country?

Since 1989—and remember that that is when the Basel Convention started—there have been over 500 attempts to export 200 million tonnes of waste from the 24 member countries of the OECD to 122 non-member countries of the OECD. The preferred countries to dump in are changing from Africa, the Pacific and Latin America. The shift is to Eastern and Central Europe, the Commonwealth of Independent States and Asia. In the negotiations to the Basel Convention the majority of countries wanted to ban trafficking in hazardous waste altogether. However, the proposal for a worldwide ban was vetoed, not surprisingly and very sadly, by the OECD countries which had the most to lose from such a ban.

As I heard Senator Margetts mention, one of the most notable exports has been lead acid batteries under the guise of recycling, sounding very friendly by that description. The problems associated with this were first brought to light when workers in less developed countries were having problems with the effects of what was supposed to be recycling plants for lead acid batteries. It was highlighted that workers were not wearing safe clothing; they were getting acid burns and even becoming blind from unsafe work practices.

In 1994 Australia was the main exporter of lead acid batteries to Indonesia. In 1992, in just one year, we exported over 11,000 tonnes of lead acid batteries compared with the United Kingdom's 700 tonnes in 1993. When a particular plant started near Jakarta, the villagers thought that it was for processing wood. However, it burned 60,000 tonnes of lead acid batteries a year, sending fumes and ash into the neighbouring rural area. The waste, which is a mixture of lead and plastic, is dumped outside the factory and is taken home by local people who melt it in woks in their backyards to extract the lead, which they then sell.

We would know, but unfortunately they would not know, in advance and we would expect the result. The result is that villagers have very high blood lead levels and are coughing blood. We would have predicted that but we, in our comfort, export to their ignorance and exploit these people, calling it recycling and feeling good about it. This is the way that we are dealing with our waste. Everyone in this parliament—because remember, we are making the laws that allow this—is responsible for such decisions.

The Democrats hope that this legislation will prevent these types of trade but we know that there are plenty of people, the sorts of shonks and brokers whom we would find in any place, who would like to get permits to take the waste off the conscience of the Australian government and then on-sell it. We hope that this will not happen. We will be watching carefully and listening to the aid groups who have been part of the discussions and the consultations to see what is happening to the waste that is exported under this amended act.

I am aware that the former government went through a two-year consultancy process with conservation and community groups and with industry. I think that process at least should be acknowledged as making an effort to follow in the right direction. Nevertheless, we still have some amendments to this legislation. The first two are to limit some rather wide-ranging powers of the minister and the last is to ensure that economic considerations are not placed ahead of safety because, as in the example I used, it is cheaper to export batteries to Indonesia but unconscionable and certainly not safe. It certainly requires further considerations other than economic ones. The constant theme of my argument in this whole area of legislation is that if we rely on the economic paradigm to determine what is appropriate behaviour then we will not necessarily end up in a socially equitable and just situation.

PARA.BREAK: The Democrats will have the opportunity to move amendments. We will not accept replacing the word `safety' with the word `effici ently', because that would put at the highest level of decision making a judgment about the economic value of following certain actions. I will detail further amendments in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak in the address-in-reply debate, I would like to join with the Governor‐General in his comments in relation to the Port Arthur massacre last week in Tasmania and, as a Western Australian senator send my sympathy and condolences to the families and friends of the victims of that tragic incident. It is no secret that victims of that tragedy came from all over the country as well as overseas. Indeed, my state did not escape the tragedy. As Australians we bound together last week to show our solidarity of support for those people who suffered as a result of this incident.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Senate adjourned on 1 December 1995, no-one quite foresaw the electoral result that occurred on 2 March this year. On 2 March this year Australian people made a significant decision. They decided to end 13 years of Labor rule and to endorse overwhelmingly the policies of the coalition. It was one of the largest margins given to a government in postwar Australia—that is, a margin in excess of 40 seats in the House of Representatives.

The coalition won the election on a sound platform which dealt with mainstream issues. Nowhere was this more evident than in my home state of Western Australia. The result in Western Australia reduced members of the opposition from six out of 14 seats to just three out of 14 seats. The coalition maintained a majority of eight seats, with the remaining three going to independents. In relation to the Senate vote, the coalition achieved 3 quotas, with that last quota going largely to the Democrats and resulting in the election of a Democrat senator.

I would like to take this opportunity to welcome two new government members in Western Australia—Mr Don Randall in the seat of Swan, formerly Mr Beazley's seat, and Ricky Johnston, who defeated George Gear, a former minister, in the seat of Canning. I also take this opportunity to welcome Dr Alan Eggleston who will be joining this chamber on 1 July.

Overall, the vote in Western Australia increased from 54 per cent to 56 per cent. When you consider that Western Australia had one of the highest coalition votes in the 1993 election, it is quite astounding. This occurred despite the dire predictions of some as to the effect that the state government and its policy would have in Western Australia. In fact, the situation was the reverse. Much of what the federal government proposes to do has already been implemented by the coalition state government in Western Australia—and I would submit has been implemented with a great deal of success.

One of our key policy areas in the lead up to the last election related to the area of industrial relations. This policy was endorsed overwhelmingly throughout Australia, but nowhere more so than in Western Australia where similar policies have been in place for some time. Some of the practical reforms proposed by this government are on similar lines. They include the development of a more decentralised industrial relations arrangement and, furthermore, the encouragement of the proliferation of workplace bargaining. The voluntary membership of unions is also going to be pursued and secondary boycotts will be outlawed. All of these policies have found a place in Western Australia and have been implemented with success.

As well as that we have seen with the state government in the west responsible financial management. I submit that at the federal election in March this year the coalition received the population's overwhelming endorsement for a responsible financial management policy. We have recently seen with the Western Australian state budget a reduction of net debt to the lowest level since June 1989. Western Australia has the lowest unemployment rate in this country, some 7.7 per cent, and, in particular, the lowest youth unemployment rate, 20.4 per cent compared with the national average of 27.8 per cent. Western Australia has one of highest growth rates in the country, all brought about by policies which are similar to those which this federal government intends to pursue.

What I am basically saying to the Senate is that the proof is in the pudding. I am referring only to my state of Western Australia. One need not go any further than Victoria to find a similar example. In Victoria, the Kennett government was returned with an overwhelming majority. This saw the endorsement of policies on similar lines to those proposed by the federal government.

PARA.BREAK: Like this federal government, the Western Australian government has targeted the training of youths. They will be trained with specialist skills so that they can find employ ment. Gone are the irrelevant programs which were designed to conceal unemployment figures. The growth of youth employment is an example of the practical policy that that state has pursued. It is no doubt the case that federally this will occur once this government has implemented similar policies.

SPEECH.PARA: Western Australia privatised the State Bank and that resulted in nearly a billion to pay off debts. I can say to this chamber that parallels can be found in relation to the privatisation of Telstra. As a result of the partial sale of Telstra it is intended that some $1 billion be paid towards an environmental debt. The environment is one of the greatest assets in this country. As with any asset, it needs investment and support. That will come from the partial sale of Telstra. That in turn will address the environmental debt that we face in this country.

This government faces a huge black hole, which has been referred to many times since the last election. It is a black hole to the extent of $8 billion. We heard the Governor‐General say that this government will embark on addressing that by cutting outlays by $4 billion in the approaching budget and then in the ensuing budget after that. That was a policy which was pursued by the governments of Victoria and Western Australia with great success. The people of Australia realise that the time has come for governments to act in a prudent fashion. We cannot afford to live beyond our means. We have to address the debt situation and we have to cut government outlays.

Native title is another area where, once again, the coalition's policies have been vindicated. At the very outset, the Western Australian government warned of the problems that would be faced with the Native Title Act. The government in Western Australia said that this Native Title Act would give nothing to indigenous people and would give nothing to the community at large. How right they are. The Premier of that state, Richard Court, was on his own and was ridiculed by the press across this country for the stand he took at the time. But has he not been proved right? It is now some two years later and there has not been one successful claim for native title. We have seen competing claims from indigenous groups over various pieces of land; we have seen case after case bogged down in a system which is unwieldy and impractical.

This government proposes amending the Native Title Act to make it workable for all concerned. That is an area where the people of Australia again spoke. They spoke through the ballot box. It was one of our key platforms. The people of Australia said, `We do not want the situation to continue. We want you as a responsible government to address this unworkable legislation.'

Generally, the coalition made it quite clear in other areas that we would not rush headlong into a republic. In fact, we proposed a people's convention, which would be made up from a variety of representatives, both political and from the wider community. Territorial and state governments would be consulted. The people, I believe, spoke quite clearly on 3 March 1996 by electing the coalition on that policy. They did not want the headlong rush into an executive style republic based on what the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, wanted. The people of Australia wanted consultation. The people of Australia want to be consulted by this government as to any changes that are proposed in relation to the constitution which has served us so well.

I remind the Senate that, when this constitution was drafted, it took some 10 years, involving various conventions across this country, before the document was finally settled. What we have is a situation where a former government capitalised on a feeling that there should be a change to the head of state for this country, and capitalised on it willy‐ nilly without any reference whatsoever to what the people really thought. I put it to the Senate that we should say, `If the people want change, so be it.' But in ascertaining whether there should be change, there should be proper consultation. I believe that we do have an Australian head of state in the Governor‐General and that we have a system of government which is second to none. I remain unconvinced at this stage that any change is warranted. However, that is just my view. There are others who have competing views which are supported by sound argument. At the end of the day, we must embark upon a process where all can be heard and where the issues can be discussed and debated.

It is also no secret that the coalition took a position on political correctness. `Political correctness' is a term which has been used to describe social engineering, the thought police and the trend to dictate what people can say and think in a political sense. We have seen it with a range of legislation introduced by the last government. Australians have always been a free people; they have always been individualistic and they have always had the desire to express their views without fear or favour. What we have seen in recent years is a growth of the feeling that, if you speak your mind, you automatically get labelled in some way. Political correctness was to be found in regulation. That is, we regulated people's thinking, we regulated people's behaviour.

Affirmative action was used in such a way. It is interesting to note that the opposition introduced a quota for women. It said that there would be a certain percentage of women in the opposition ranks and that this regulation would dictate to the members of that party in the selection of candidates. It is interesting to see that, at the last election, there was a dramatic increase of female representation in the House of Representatives. It did not come from the opposition; it came from the government. I might add that it came without any quota, it came without any regulation, because the approach from this side of the chamber was that you did not need to regulate people's thinking—you choose the best person for the job. And that is how it should be.

I believe that there are some refreshing changes in the wind for Australia. This is a government which will govern not only for the city but for the country as well. Regional Australia has a lot of disadvantage. I come from a resources based state where farming, mining, forestry and fishing are big income earners for this country. Invariably, the state of Western Australia produces no less than 25 per cent of this country's export income. That largely comes from regional Australia. So I welcomed the Governor‐General's comments in relation to the development of the rural enterprise network program and the rural development incentive program. I believe that, with these sorts of programs and the consultation that this government will embark on in regional Australia, we will address the issues and disadvantage suffered in the more remote areas of this country.

During the campaign I had the opportunity to travel to the far north of my state and there saw first‐hand the disadvantage that people have by way of the cost of living, the cost of freight and the fact that workers are flown in and flown out because employers do not want to provide a house or motor vehicle—there are fringe benefits tax implications. What that does is detract from the infrastructure of those mining and pastoral towns. In those areas you need more people for the infrastructure so you can have schools, hospitals and public facilities, which will encourage people to live and work in those areas. That is so important for this country, which has seen a centralisation of unprecedented proportions—by far the majority of our population live in five capital cities.

I believe the government is on a solid course with its policies as outlined by the Governor‐General. Not only will it be a fiscally responsible government but such things as health, housing, income support and community services will be dealt with more fairly. The government has outlined its incentives for the states to deliver more palliative care. The government is committed to the establishment of a Commonwealth dental program and the government has made a commitment to meet by 2001 the full demand for work‐related child care. It is a government that will deal responsibly with taxpayers' funds and will see that the good management of such funding goes to help all Australians.

In last week's Newspoll we saw increased support for the government. This is despite the publicity given to the impending budget cuts. In my own state of Western Australia a recent Morgan poll put the government ahead on a two‐party preferred basis, 60 per cent versus 40 per cent. A more recent Westpoll showed that in Western Australia the government commanded 48 per cent of the vote as opposed to only 30 per cent for the ALP opposition.

Those figures come in the face of this government stating very clearly what it intends to do. Not only did the people of Australia give us a resounding endorsement on 2 March this year, but they continue to do so. Not only does this side of the chamber receive such support for its programs and policies in a federal sense, but it also does so on a state basis. To see this, one has only to look at the success of coalition governments among the state governments of Australia.

We are on the right track. When this government faces the people in three years time in an election, it will be able to do so with a clear conscience and will be able to go back to the people of Australia and say, `We did what we set out to do and we have delivered to you a sound financial budget and a situation where Australia is a fairer country, where taxpayers' moneys have been managed on a more accountable basis and, above all, where you are a lot freer in what you can do, say and think.' If we achieve that in three years we will be doing very well.

But we in this chamber have to be allowed to do what we promised the Australian people we would do. That is something the opposition needs to remember if it—indeed, any minor party in this chamber—is to remain relevant. If it thought that the people of Australia were of the opinion that we would be elected in the lower house to do something and then have, in the Senate, a different result so that we could not do it, it would be on the wrong track, because the government is formed in the other place. That is where the people of Australia very clearly made their choice as to the government.

It is not the case that, by a majority not being delivered to the government in the Senate, the people said, `We want you to do one thing but we do not want you to do another.' That is certainly not the case. The people of Australia have seen fit to have a check and balance in this chamber but it is not one which is to obstruct the good government of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wheelwright, Sen Thomas

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in the address‐in‐reply debate, I would like to address my remarks to the sale of Telstra. I know that at this stage we do not have the legislation before the Senate, although it has come before the lower house, but there are some things that can be said about this whole notion of the sale of Telstra without reference to the legislation—concerning general questions which arise from the whole process without regard to the specific legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take the following viewpoint: many people on our side, and people in the minor parties, will argue about the whole principle of selling public assets but my concern is that even if you wanted to sell Telstra, even if you had decided you wanted to sell Telstra, you certainly would not do it now, under the market conditions that prevail at present.

A number of things have to be taken into account when looking at the sale of something as massive as Telstra. In terms of earnings, it is probably the biggest company in Australia. The first concern that I would have is that the government has not provided any of the industrial, regulatory framework which would exist once Telstra has been sold.

The previous government provided quite extensive draft recommendations for the world post‐30 June 1997. That post‐1997 document was circulated extensively through the industry and attracted quite a bit of comment from various industry players. It provided an understanding of the structure under which the players would operate, and in particular it provided shareholders of Optus with a notion of what their company would be worth, because it explained very clearly what sorts of constraints would act upon that company in terms of it making a profit.

But the present government has not given any such undertaking that they will provide a regulatory framework. They have not given any undertakings to the Senate or to anyone else about what sort of world a privatised Telstra would exist in. The government seem hell‐bent upon providing the legislation to the Senate, as they have to the lower House, for the sale of Telstra.

But, when it comes to when they will tell us what the world will be like post‐July 1997, all we are told by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) is, according to his remarks to the ATUG conference last week, he will get a green paper together with all sorts of options for post‐1997 and it will be available in about a month; he will then get the different industry players together around a table to have a chat about it; and perhaps in September this year we might see some sort of draft legislation come before the Senate with a hope it might be enacted by the end of the year.

But in the meantime the minister wants the Senate to approve the sale of Telstra. He has made that perfectly clear. So we are in a position where the Senate is really being asked to fly blind. We are being asked to approve the sale of Telstra, a massive public asset, without any indication at all from the government about what the industry framework will be past the middle of next year.

That is absolutely crucial to consumers of telecommunications services in Australia because, as anyone can tell us, all of the benefits that consumers have enjoyed over the last few years have derived from the introduction of competition and the industry framework which the previous government put in place. None of these things were available when Telstra was a monopoly. In fact, the old Telecom was a very difficult organisation to deal with. It certainly was not consumer orientated.

It was the introduction of a viable competitor, being Optus, that really provided the lower charges and the better services that people have come to take for granted now. Prior to then, there was simply no need whatever for Telstra to provide any of these sorts of services and no real stimulus for them to do it. So the whole issue of industry structure is absolutely crucial to the world of a privatised Telstra, or indeed any other telecommunications company.

It has to be recognised too that we are in the very early stages of deregulation of the telecommunications market. I can quite confidently say that Optus would be very quickly gobbled up by a privatised Telstra. It is the case now that Optus, while it has now turned to making a small profit, certainly does not have the financial strength or the market strength that Telstra has. It was my view, certainly prior to the last election, that steps had to be taken to make sure that Optus was maintained as a viable competitor with Telstra, given that it was crucial to all of the consumer benefits which flowed from Telstra.

The position is that Telstra is now making more money as a competitor with Optus than it was as a monopolist. All of the money which it is making now derives from the fact that competition was introduced. But more important than that, for the purposes of this debate, is that Telstra is awash with cash. There is an argument that Telstra is in actual fact overcapitalised. Certainly a view of the previous government was that it was appropriate to raise the dividend and to improve the return to the shareholder of Telstra because so much cash was pouring into the organisation.

That is certainly not true of Optus. Optus is a new player. Optus, with a massive commitment in front of it to capital expenditure for cable roll out and the like, does not have the same sorts of cash revenues available to it as Telstra does. Because it cannot compete in the local call market, in the telephony market, it will be some time before it will have access to that sort of cash, whereas Telstra, on the other hand, is more than capable of funding all of its current capital expenditure requirements, quite considerable though they may be, from the amount of cash flowing into the organisation.

So there is no equality at all between Optus and Telstra, and there will be no equality between Optus and Telstra for some time to come. It is the regulatory framework which the previous government has set up and which this government will have to set up post‐1997 which will determine the balance between Optus and Telstra and therefore the sorts of consumer benefits which consumers are used to at present.

There is another consideration too when we look at the capital structure of the two companies. In selling Telstra, what the government is looking for is a greater commitment from the Australian capital markets than they have produced hereto. Generally speaking, the Australian stock market can provide about $12 billion to $15 billion per annum in new issues. Net of dividend reinvestment plans and all the rest, you can normally count on about $12 billion to $15 billion.

Last year it was only $11 billion, so it cannot be assumed that it is always somewhere in that range. But let us, for the purposes of argument, say that the market can provide some $12 billion to $15 billion—and that, might I say, is without any restriction on foreign ownership. That is just the general take‐up of new issues. Yet we are being asked to believe that the Australian stock market can absorb in one hit some $8 billion in new issue from one company—not $12 billion to $15 billion across all companies, not $12 billion to $15 billion where they can spread their risk over the hundreds of companies which come to the market every year, but $8 billion by one company.

It is an absolutely massive ask from the Australian stock market, and it is not one that you particularly want to do now. Might I emphasise that we are not talking about the normal conditions of a new issue, where really it is for all comers. We are talking about $8 billion where there are severe restrictions on foreign participation. So they are not getting the $8 billion from just the Australian stock market as they normally would but getting the overwhelming proportion of it from only domestic institutions. Of course, if it is only domestic institutions who are providing the funds, that will obviously drive the price down.

One of the reasons why we brought forward the 1997 review was that the capital markets are there for not only Telstra; they are also there for Optus. You have to consider the fact that Optus will also be going to the stock market at the same time. There is a need at present for Optus to raise something like $300 million or $400 million from the same stock market. Rather than being in the position they were in under the post-1997 rules which the previous government provided—where they could go to the market, establish themselves as a viable competitor and get adequately funded—they now have to compete with the prospect of Telstra, or so this government would have us believe.

BREAK.PARA: You are doing two things: you are getting less for Telstra than you otherwise would and you are making it more difficult for Optus to raise the capital which it badly needs. At the same time you are not providing any sort of regulative guarantees for shareholders as to how much money they can make, where the profitable areas of the company are going to be and what constraints there are on their profitability in terms of the industry framework.

Indeed, when you reflect upon the whole process of going to the markets you see that there is a fundamental conflict between the good of the consumer and the highest price you can get for Telstra. This is one of the things which the government has belatedly started to struggle with.

The government has now said, `The community service obligation is going to provide for everything.' The community service obligation, which was enacted by the previous government, is now going to cover everything. The government has sought surreptitiously, in the bill it has presented to the lower House, to incorporate the community service obligation within the act. The problem with that is that you cannot cover everything.

Anybody who knows anything about accounting, particularly within an organisation the size of Telstra, knows that it is impossible to go to every single customer and work out what the degree of subsidy is for each individual customer. We introduced a process of calculating the CSO which was rough and ready; it served its purpose, but it would in no way satisfy a private shareholder.

Let me give you an indication of the sorts of numbers we are talking about. In my duty electorate of New England the degree of subsidy on a rough basis that Telstra has calculated and the figures it supplied to Austel were $1,940 per line per year in Armidale, $2,410 in Barraba, $2,300 in Glen Innes, $1,030 in Inverell and $780 in Tamworth. We are not talking about small amounts of money.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two thousand seven hundred in Darwin.

—I am sure it would be much greater in Darwin, and Darwin would probably be an easier place to service than all of the outlying areas in the Northern Territory. These are the difficulties involved in calculating a community service obligation.

BREAK.PARA: There are a number of things which cannot be calculated or presently are not calculated by community service obligation. For example, Telstra last year under the previous government introduced a number of TTY typewriters for the use of hearing‐impaired and dumb people. Those people were able to contact their loved ones, their relatives and so on by using public TTY facilities and TTY facilities in their own homes. Indeed, they could communicate with each other. Given the fact that they cannot use a telephone normally, it was obviously a considerable social benefit to them.

None of that was calculated by the CSO and it is very difficult to calculate it in terms of the CSO. That is only one example of the number of things which are covered by a CSO which are not currently costed and which would be very difficult to cost. The present government suggests that the CSO is going to satisfy all of the requirements that we need, all of the things which consumers are concerned about under privatisation, but that clearly is not the case.

There is this conflict between getting the best possible price for Telstra and serving the consumer. The interest of the private shareholders must be paramount to the directors of Telstra post-float. The interests of the private shareholders are integral to their directors' responsibilities. Even though we are talking about selling only a third of the company, even though we are not talking about selling the whole company, even if there is only a third of it owned by private shareholders, their interests have to be safeguarded by the directors.

The directors have a primary responsibility, which is reflected in the Stock Exchange regulations and every other part of the ASC code, to look after the benefit of those shareholders. Their responsibility is to maximise the return to those private shareholders—not to the other shareholders; not to the government, which may be patient and which may have a concern, indeed an electoral concern, about the benefits which are flowing to the consumer. Their responsibility is to maximise the return to the private shareholders, to maximise the value to them.

In one respect, saying that we are going to do it only a little bit really makes no difference at all. Once you allow private shareholders into a company, as indeed the previous government found with the Commonwealth Bank, they become paramount. It is a furphy to suggest that somehow it still remains in public ownership and therefore all of the benefits which consumers are concerned about in regional areas in New South Wales and the Northern Territory are going to be protected. Really it is the interest of private shareholders that will become paramount once you get two private shareholders, let alone once you sell a third of the company.

The other consideration which has got absolutely no airing from this government at all is that they are asking the Australian stock market to buy Telstra when the Australian stock market, I am sad to say, has been a very poor performer. When I ceased working in the Australian stock market in February of 1994 the stock market was just over 2,300 on the all ordinaries; last Friday it was 2,299. There has been absolutely no movement in the Australian stock market since I left.

The suggestion that Senator O'Chee will put forward is that the stock market is going to improve. But, in order to be able to get more out of the Australian stock market than anybody has so far been able to get, we are going to have to get a better performance over the next few years than we have had over the last two. That is an extraordinary position for a government to put itself in—that it is going to make itself hostage to the Australian stock market to fulfil what is a very rigorous legislative program and to do it all in order to keep what it believes are its commitments prior to the next election.

There is absolutely no flexibility involved in the government's plans. You might mention Qantas, but the previous government twice withdrew Qantas from the market because of market conditions. There is no such flexibility allowed in the government's plans, absolutely no flexibility at all. They have to get this done with breakneck speed. I understand, from public statements which Senator Hill has made, that he wants this Senate to pass the legislation and is quite happy to maximise the pressure on this Senate and not wait for the new senators to take their place.

There is no flexibility in their plans whatever in terms of market conditions. I must say, to be long in the market is a very uncomfortable position to be in. I have seen people who have exposed themselves to the stock market and it is not a pretty sight. The sight of Mr Costello, Senator Short or Mr Fahey kneeling beside their bed at night praying that the stock market is going to go up does not fill me with any great glee, although it may be so much the better for every other stockholder. But to say that they are going to do it and be exposed to the stock market to the degree of $8 billion is an absolutely massive ask. I have never seen anybody take an $8 billion punt on the Australian stock market. They will not just be sweating; they will be sweating blood.

The other argument which is sometimes put up is that there is somehow some similarity between the sale of the Commonwealth Bank and the sale of Qantas. There is a fundamental difference between the sale of those other two entities and the sale of Telstra. If you were to equate the two positions, you would say that selling Telstra now is the same as selling the Commonwealth Bank in 1983, prior to all the deregulation of the financial markets, prior to any of the entry of foreign banks, prior to any floating of the Australian dollar and prior to all the changes which the Labor government brought in through the 1980s. That is the equivalent to selling Telstra now.

The Commonwealth Bank, back in 1983, was one of only four banks in the country. It was very inefficient, even by its own admission. It was providing far less to its shareholder then than it subsequently did after the period of deregulation. It was also acting in a very immature market. We can, with the wisdom of hindsight, see just how immature the Australian financial market was back in 1983. All of the great changes which the Labor government brought in had yet to happen. That would have to be possibly the worst time you could ever envisage selling the Commonwealth Bank.

The same thing is true with Qantas. Senator Bob Collins would be able to back me up when I say that all of the changes which the Labor government brought into the domestic airlines industry were massively to the benefit of Qantas. It became far more efficient, growth in the market was exceptional and it became far more profitable. You would not have wanted to try to sell Qantas back in 1983. Back in 1983, Qantas had a very poor record of profitability. It staggered from profit to loss, profit to loss. It was massively inefficient and therefore provided a very poor return to the shareholder. Anybody who suggested that selling Qantas back in 1983 was a good idea was clearly underselling the Australian public. That is exactly what the government is doing now by saying that it wants to sell Telstra.

We have seen only the tip of the iceberg when it comes to the changes in telecommunications that are taking place around the world. To start talking about selling Telstra now, prior to all of those changes coming in, prior to there being any stable industry framework even being suggested by the government, is absolutely ludicrous. You are selling short the Australian people. There is no doubt that Telstra, when it is a mature player in a mature market with lots of other competitors, will be a far better prospect for sale sometime down the track than it is going to be now. That is essentially the difference between selling the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas and trying to sell Telstra now.

People will argue the question about whether the government should sell public assets and all of the other considerations that go with that. The fact is that 60 per cent of Australians do not want the thing sold, but I am not making reference to those arguments. I am simply saying, by the government's own logic, if you wanted to sell this entity, you would not sell it now. You have to reflect upon what is rather unseemly haste on the part of the government. Why is it that they are so keen to get this sale through? Why is it that they want to bring this bill before the Senate, before there is even any suggestion about bringing any proposals to the Senate about the post‐1997 framework? Why do they want to get on with the job without any sort of framework at all for the sale?

One thing that occurred to me, and which I think should be in the back of every senator's mind, is the degree of pork barrelling which went into the last election. Certainly, we had Mr Sharp and Mr Costello, prior to the election, talking about what could be done with the proceeds of Telstra and the improvements to the highways of New South Wales, which is my state. I am keenly interested to know where the money for that is going to come from. But let us leave that aside. There is no link between Telstra and the environment. A number of speakers have now pointed that out, including Senator Kernot.

It is absolutely ridiculous to suggest that the plans the government wants to bring in have to be brought in by the sale of Telstra. If they had a real commitment to the environment, they would do it anyway. Certainly that was the policy which the Labor government put up to the last election, and it is one that can be enacted by anyone. The fact of the matter is that this government has no commitment to the environment at all because if they had they would not make it conditional. Commitment is something you make without making it conditional. This is the sore point. They know that it is conditional and they know the commitment is not there. All they are doing is looking for an excuse not to do anything about the environment. They want to put the onus not on themselves as a government, but on other senators, other political parties for funding the environment.

They have created this spurious $8 billion figure, which they cannot abide by in the next August budget, which was irrelevant when they first mentioned it in the Senate and which has been overtaken by further forecasting work by the Joint Economic Forecasting Group in April. This spurious number was never here for any other purpose than to bring back Fightback. The motivation behind the sale of Telstra is exactly the same thing. There is no concern in here for the consumer, there is no concern in here for people in rural and regional New South Wales—my own state—and there is no concern to see those people do any better. We saw the minister make an absolute fool of himself today when he tried to explain why it was that selling down Telstra into private ownership in any way made it more inefficient, in any way provided any benefit to the consumer. Quite clearly, it does not.

As I indicated before, the sorts of things that the government seem to be relying upon in the legislation they have suggested to the lower house will in no way deliver the benefits that the consumer derives at the moment. The decision to sell Telstra at the present time is ill‐thought‐out, badly timed and the act of a very desperate government.

All we can garner from the government's attempt to sell Telstra now is that everything the previous government said about the fiscal position is true: there is no money there and those opposite knew before the last election campaign that there was no money there. The present government went into that campaign knowing that if they were going to promise anything, given all of the other pork‐barrelling commitments they had made in Tasmania and northern New South Wales, they would have to hive off their environment policy and pay for it separately. It was the only way they could make ends meet.

This decision has nothing to do with benefits for the consumer or for the rest of Australia; it is entirely to do with saving the government's fiscal skin and paying for the pork‐barrelling that they indulged in in the election campaign. To sell Telstra is the only way for them to do that. If they do it now they will get far less for it than they would if they waited until they had a mature industry with other competitive players. That was the example with the Commonwealth Bank, that was the example with Qantas—and this is exactly the same.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to remind senators, particularly opposition senators, of the pur pose of the address‐in‐reply debate. On 2 March the Australian people voted—comprehensively—to throw out those opposite. The people of Australia voiced their resentment of the former government's arrogance and excesses.

SPEECH.PARA: My contribution today, therefore, will compare and contrast what has happened with what is planned for the future. As the Governor‐General said in his speech last Tuesday, in electing a coalition government the people endorsed decisively a comprehensive program of practical reform. The Liberal and National parties will keep faith with the people and implement that program.

What disturbs me is that on virtually every single solitary day that has passed since 2 March we have heard Labor senators or members, Democrat senators, or in particular independent Green senators, talk about the legislation that they are going to block. Today we had a classic example. Senator Cook asked Minister Short whether the government would keep its promises. The simple answer is: we want to keep our promises. We want to be a totally different government from that which has ruled this country for the last 13 years. We want to be an honest government. The simple answer to Senator Cook and those opposite is that we will keep our promises as much as they will let us.

We have just heard a contribution from Senator Wheelwright on the sale of Telstra. Clearly, he and the Labor Party are opposed to the sale of Telstra. The Democrats are also opposed to the sale of Telstra; yet they had the gall, the cheek, the nerve, to reinvigorate their original slogan of `keeping the bastards honest'. How can anybody profess to have that slogan when part and parcel of their platform is to stop us from implementing an honest policy. It is absolutely and utterly absurd.

Once again I highlight the difference between us and the former government. The policy for the sale of Telstra is a classic example to highlight that difference. We went to the public with the policy, opened up and said, `There it is.' The contrast with the Labor Party is that in election after election they promised not to sell Qantas and not to sell the Commonwealth Bank—to name but two. They also went on to promise not to increase taxes and made other promises.But we all know what happened to Qantas. We all know what happened to the Commonwealth Bank. They were sold.

At least we had the honesty to say what we would do. We put our policies up front and the people voted for them. Yet we have virtually the entire opposite side of this chamber prepared to block that honest policy and proposal. In fact at question time today we had some dill ask us whether we were going to keep our promises. Really! You cannot have it both ways. The things that we have said we want to do were highlighted in the Governor‐General's speech:
. to boost the competitiveness and productivity of the Australian economy and thereby deliver higher economic growth and higher living standards;
. to raise national savings;
. to lift burdens from the small business sector so that it can generate new jobs; and
. to tackle the longer term environmental challenges such as soil degradation, salinity and the protection of our coastline and waterways.

A number of these things would not have been necessary if we had had a half‐decent government over the last 13 years. But that was not so. The reality is that we had a self‐indulgent government that thought more about itself and its mates than about anything to do with the Australian population. One of the primary reasons that those opposite got thrown out comprehensively on 2 March—I know they still have difficulty coming to terms with that—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at all.
—That's good.
—We recognise what happened.

—At least if you understand what happened you might support the things that we are trying to do for the future. One of the primary causes of your dismissal from government was the indulgence of the former Prime Minister, the indulgence of ministers, the indulgence of certain sections of the trade union movement and the indulgence of your mates. The indul gence started right from the top. Let us face it: you had true leadership in the indulgence stakes and real leadership in the indulgence stakes.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us just look at the fact that Mr Keating decided that, while he was running ads and everything else to buy Australian, and everyone else in Australia was trying to do so, the leadership of the country, the Prime Minister of the country, saw fit to try to snaffle off into the Lodge a $30,000 teak table. Nothing Australian about that at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honestly!
—`Honestly' says Senator West, as though it does not matter, as though those things do not matter. Let us go on with some of your other indulgences.

SPEECH.PARA: The leadership of this country in the indulgence stakes ensured that his home renovations went on to include a $261,000 carport. A carport worth $261,000 is worth twice as much as the average person's home. Then there was a $2,600 clothesline; $8,250 worth of antique lights. But with the revamped Lodge with which the Prime Minister saw fit to indulge himself, he then decided to throw a few parties. The gabbling senators over on the other side were probably present at one of them because one of them was for 100 of his Labor mates. How far do these lavish indulgences go? They were not allowed to continue because the people of Australia decided `enough was enough'—it sounds good enough to be a slogan. Not surprisingly, Mr Keating, when asked how much he had spent in total on such parties and activities, was tight-lipped. No wonder he called the taxpayers and everybody else scumbags; anyone who had a right or responsibility to ask him the difficult questions was just simply abused. Therein lies another reason for the Labor Party being thrown out: the people of Australia wanted a different administration; they wanted a different type of administration.

All the while, of course, it should be remembered that Paul Keating was presiding over a government which was responsible for record youth unemployment, massive general unemployment, a record foreign debt, record bankruptcies, 16 consecutive quarters of debt in excess of $140 billion and a current account deficit of $27 billion. All the time that that was happening—the Prime Minister and his scallywags were all indulging themselves—a million people were unemployed.

We get on to areas of waste in various departments and agencies. We had a few questions last week and again today directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron). The thing that staggers me is that those on the opposition side have the gall and the nerve even to ask the questions in the first place. The reason for the problems with health, housing, education and living standards among the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities comes right back to point one: the Labor Party. Once again, while they were spending all their time indulging themselves, it was those very people who were suffering. Today, we are now being asked how we are going to correct the lack of activity that has gone on for 13 years. That would be a fair question if it were coming from someone who was independent. But for it to come from the perpetrators of the excesses is a little over the top.

This ex-government, for example, gave a huge tick to the spending of $425,000 on a house on Thursday Island for an ATSIC commissioner; it came complete with white goods, carpet and bedding. The expenditure on this house alone instantly consumed one-fiftieth of the total Commonwealth allocation for Aboriginal housing programs in Australia. If I were someone from the Labor Party, that is not something that I would be particularly proud of. But this is the type of attitude they had.

Consultancies were, of course, the flavour of the month—flavour of the month? Pardon the pun: they were the flavour of the month for 13 years. In the two financial years 1993-94 and 1994-95, the Labor Party spent taxpayers' money to the equivalent of $545,000 on public relations consultants for the Department of Veterans' Affairs and a further $40,000 on the dissemination of media statements on veterans' affairs; meanwhile, the department of tourism spent $300,000 on hiring two consultants to provide information on ecotourism.

In fact, the involvement of consultants in government departments increased 460 per cent between 1985 and 1995, with spending blowing out from $27 million to about $342 million. Before anyone says, `Well, so what! You are all as bad as each other', let me just explain the difference between what the Labor Party has done and what we have already put in place.

Junior ministers will have a $10,000 pay cut; a 20 per cent cut in the ministerial component of their salaries. That is the first thing. Ministerial appointments have been reduced from 30 to 28. Ministerial staffing levels have been reduced from 365 under Mr Keating's administration to 295, saving $5 million. The National Media Liaison Service and the Ministerial Media Group have been disbanded. Consultants have been reduced from 40 to one. There is the mark of a government that means business in terms of cutting back on those excesses and saying, `We mean what we say and we say what we mean.' Therefore, we have a very different attitude.

As an example I will just take the National Media Liaison Service. The idea of a National Media Liaison Service sounds like a pretty good show to the average Joe Blow in the street. Basically, day in and day out we are still seeing questions generated by the remnants of the National Media Liaison Service. Ministers are being asked questions which are prefaced by the words, `On XYZ radio program you said ABCDE.' The questioners have not generated these questions themselves; the questions come from the remnants of the National Media Liaison Service which worked exclusively for the Labor Party and not in the interests of the community. That is where all this material is being generated. We have scrapped that.

We could have kept that service and said, `Ah ha! What you did for 13 years to us we will now do to you.' No, we have taken the taxpayers' interest to heart and we have scrapped the whole shooting match. Of course, in the true blase spirit of Labor's accountability standards there is no comprehensive record available which would indicate the number of consultants who were employed or how much each was paid. Those things have also been kept secret.

I turn to specific examples of waste in the day‐to‐day administration of some of the departments. The coalition is keen to start on counting forward, as the minister has said, but I am not going to deal with that. The Department of Social Security is often under the microscope for wastefulness. This is the department which is charged with the mandate of granting financial assistance to those who genuinely need help. The department should be most scrupulous as to how the money is spent. But, by way of specific example, last September the department spent about $2.5 million on a glossy promotional brochure called Your family and you which was mailed to 1.8 million Australian families. This followed the expenditure of $1.6 million on the promotion of the home child‐care allowance which was soon after scrapped and replaced by the parenting allowance.

I do not for one moment suggest that the people from the department went to bed one night, dreamt this idea up, and went to work the next day and implemented it. This was all done at the instructions of an excessive Labor government which was desperate to be re‐elected and just dipped its hand into the taxpayers' pocket every time it wanted more money. The mere fact that we see $2.5 million spent on one brochure and $1.6 million on another is neither here nor there. It does not worry the Labor Party because it is not the Labor Party's money; it is the taxpayers' money.

I recall another example. In July last year the department erroneously paid out $100,000 in benefits. It had earlier incorrectly paid $4 million in benefits to pensioners and sent concession cards to 37,700 people who had no entitlement to them—including 12,600 people who had died.

I wonder why a government would need to spend $4,995 on a single coffee machine for the branches of the Australian Taxation Office, and why the judges of the Family Court of Australia needed $10,000‐worth of Wedgwood china crockery. Why would a government need to spend $1 million to herald the arrival of a new polymer $20 note when the old one was going to be withdrawn and we had no choice whether to use the old or the new. This is simply a further example of how the former government decided to spend the taxpayers' money. It is a further example of why that government was comprehensively thrown out of office on 2 March.

I wonder whether taxpayers had an obligation to foot the massive legal bill of Dr Carmen Lawrence. The people decided that they did not have a responsibility to foot her legal bill. The people threw out the government that sanctioned that payment. Dr Lawrence had no right to that money—none whatsoever. The royal commission last year had nothing to do with Dr Lawrence's status as health minister in the previous government; it had everything to do with her not telling the truth while she was Premier of Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —And subsequently.

—And subsequently, as Senator Vanstone quite rightly says. Dr Lawrence compounded the problem by going on to deny that there was a problem. Of course, she received a blank cheque for her legal expenses. By contrast, only 1.9 per cent of legal aid users are ever funded for costs in excess of $10,000. Contrast that with the case of Dr Lawrence—`Blank cheque; whatever you want, you've got it.' Most legal aid claimants received less than $1,500 worth of legal assistance. I doubt that any of them had a salary of $130,000 per annum such as Dr Lawrence received when her legal costs soared to about $800,000. BREAK.PARA: And I wonder if the former government really needed to spend $10 million on air travel in the 1994-95 financial year. I wonder why the then Minister for Finance, the now Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley, thought the coalition was churlish for questioning that expenditure. I also wonder why the former Prime Minister spent $624,095 of taxpayers' money on a nine‐day trip to Germany, where he participated in a debate on German composers.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?
—It was $624,095, Senator Vanstone.
—For nine days?
—For a nine‐day trip to Germany for a debate on German composers.
—Who was it?

—Who else? It was the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating. That is not a bad effort. Mr Acting Deputy Presi dent, I have deliberately gone through some of those excesses. I would love to have a couple of hours to go through the rest of them, but I think it is very important—as I said at the beginning of my speech—to compare and contrast exactly what we are doing. We recognise the job of work that we have ahead of us. The reason we have such a massive job of work ahead of us relates to the very examples that I have laid down here in the Senate today.

BREAK.PARA: The reform of the labour market is essential. We, as we said during the campaign, intend to govern for all Australians, not just for sections of the trade union movement and not with the ACTU sitting at the cabinet table. Jennie George and Bill Kelty and their mates are yet to come to terms with the fact that they lost. Every time I see them on television I feel like nudging them and saying, `Hey, hasn't anyone told you you lost?' They are equally determined to ensure that they are going to create as much strife in the work force as they possibly can. The reason is that they know that their viability is at risk. The membership of trade unions is sliding and it will continue to slide.

There is a responsibility of this government to get higher efficiency and productivity which will raise our international competitiveness and, as the Governor-General said, open up new export opportunities. That has to be done through labour market reform. It was an essential plank of our election commitments—an essential plank of our election commitments that both the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats want to see nosedive. You cannot ask us in Senate question time whether or not we are going to keep our proposals and policies if, at every single solitary turn, you are saying that you are not going to vote for anything. You cannot have it both ways.

We are also going to bring back effective sanctions against secondary boycotts. That has been one of the things that the Labor Party has always believed is okay—for people to hold businesses hostage for some other purpose. That is no longer going to happen. There is a change of guard in this town and it is all going to be different.

We are also going to reduce the red tape and the unnecessary paperwork for small business. One of the problems is that we have people in the Labor Party and in the Democrats who have never had to run a business. They have never paid the bills, they have never paid the pay cheques, they have never paid out workers compensation, they have never paid the electricity, the telephone bills, the rent—and the list goes on. They do not have an understanding, for one moment, of the impact of fringe benefits tax and the absolutely enormous degree of paperwork it involves.
