It has been a little while—it has probably been six months or so—since I looked through the Parliamentary Handbook to look at how many people on the other side of parliament had actually run a business. I think I was battling to find two. Therein lies an understanding of the problem: people cannot comprehend how there is a gulf of difference between a trade union mentality on one side and a business attitude on the other side. Business is going to provide jobs, provide prosperity and provide a far more buoyant economy. What the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats are saying is that they will block our business, block our bills and block our election commitments and promises. That is simply not on.

I go further and look at some of the commitments that the Governor-General mentioned in his speech, such as the commitment to reducing the economic pressure on families, especially those with dependent children. That should have been done in 13 years of Labor government, but it was not. Likewise, a comprehensive retirement incomes policy should have been developed in the last 13 years to ensure that older people have financial security in their retirement.

Equally, young Australians should have a better opportunity for the future than they have today. They have been treated very shabbily. To think that we have the highest levels of youth unemployment that this country has ever had and the Labor Party is proud of that is nothing short of a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a misrepresentation.

—I am glad I heard someone over there say, `We are not proud of it.' No wonder you got thrown out because the people of Australia were not proud it, either. The young people of our country should be the resource of tomorrow. You treated them as the rubbish dump of tomorrow, and that is not good enough. That is why it is important to ensure that changes are made, that there is a view to the future, not only for young people but for regional and rural Australia—for the society in toto. The Labor Party did everything it could to throw a spanner in the works for country people. They operated on the basis that `They will never vote for us anyway, so it does not matter'. Fortunately, there has been a changing of the guard in Canberra and in Australia and we will see a better society as a consequence.

I would first of all like to associate myself very closely with the Governor-General's opening words, his commiserations and expressions of condolences and sympathy to all of those who lost friends, relatives or injured themselves and to the emergency workers and service workers who provided the assistance in Tasmania. SPEECH.PARA: After that, with all due respect to His Excellency, I find that the information that has been given to him by his government is lacking. It is a bereft document. SPEECH.PARA: There are a few issues that the coalition keeps pushing. They keep talking about the `$8 billion black hole'. It is important that we dispel that myth very early in the piece. In regard to Access Economics and other economic analysts, the $8 billion black hole they talk about is a forecast. When we are talking about forecasts I suggest we ask what people think about the weather bureau. They are the people who do most of the forecasts that we are aware of. Everyone comments about how inaccurate the weather bureau can be or how those forecasts can change. That is something that this lot opposite us have failed to recognise—that it is a forecast.

The figure is at the maximum put at $4.9 billion. But before they start crowing about that size, they should also be cognisant of the fact that $2.5 billion of that are changes that were forced upon the savings part of the last year's budget. Those changes were forced upon the government by the Senate. Coalition support was needed for the amendments to be agreed to. So one has to wonder how serious the government is about making real savings to government spending when the coalition last year cut $2.5 billion worth of savings out of the government's budget. That would indicate a bit of a two bob each way attitude.

One needs to remember also what happened in March of 1983, when we came into power. The Treasury Secretary John Stone estimated that the headline budget deficit for 1993-94 was $9.6 billion, in 1983 terms. The GDP in 1983-84 was $195 billion. Therefore, the deficit of the GDP in 1983 was 4.9 per cent. In 1996-97 dollar terms, the 1983 deficit is $24.5 billion. The coalition's estimate from the Treasury for the 1996 budget deficit is $4.9 billion. The GDP for 1996 is around $5 billion. Therefore, the deficit as a percentage is less than one per cent of GDP.

Now let us compare apples with apples and look at who are the better economic managers. It is far better if there is a less than one per cent deficit as opposed to a 4.9 per cent deficit. That point needs to be remembered by people out there.

So what is the government planning to do about this deficit? They are going to make cuts. They will not tell us what programs are going to be cut. They are going to make big and savage cuts. BREAK.PARA: Another issue I want to canvass is the government's lack of action—and that is the only way to describe it—upon the announcement of the closure of the 14 or 15 regional tax offices in rural Australia. They have done nothing. It might be nasty of me to think—

I call upon the current minister to direct the tax office to review this situation and increase the tax facilities and services that are provided to rural areas.

BREAK.PARA: We already have the tax offices there, but the government has done nothing about it.

I am pleased to see that the IRC has put a temporary stop to proceedings, but the government has done nothing about directing the tax office to reopen these facilities and extend the services available.

I had a very interesting conversation with a gentleman who had been the manager of a regional tax office. He was able to tell me that the amount of work that regional tax offices were able to do was much greater than that which could be done in the tax offices in the city. I thought that was very interesting, given the government's keenness to make sure that things were more productive. An area where there is greater productivity is in the regional tax office. In the past, the productivity of regional tax offices has been greater than that of the city offices but, by all appearances, the government is not going to stop the closures.

Another area where there will be government cuts is Worksafe Australia. The farming industry is the third most dangerous in Australia, and I would have thought that the National Party would have been very interested to express its concern about what the effects of the possible closure of Farmsafe would be, but we heard nothing.

The final issue I wish to deal with tonight is Telstra. I very much support the motion that was moved by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) about Telstra. I have great concerns about what the partial sale of Telstra will mean to rural people. We do not know what the long-term plans are for Telstra, because on 6PR during the election campaign the now Prime Minister said:

I don't know. We may decide at the end of the first term that all you need do is sell a third. On the other hand we may . . . people may feel its gone so well the most sensible thing to do is to sell some more. I don't know.
That is the sort of vision this government has for the country. They really do not know.

We also had Senator Alston saying during the campaign, and again in here, that the thing that counts with Telstra is the bottom line. I live in an area that benefits from cross‐subsidisation. For the life of me, I cannot see how, if you sell off a third of Telstra and you have to maximise the return to those private shareholders within the company, cross‐subsidisation will not be eroded by at least a third. But that is something that the government is not yet able to tell us.

Cross‐subsidisation occurs in a number of areas. It occurs on the annual line fees and it occurs when a new service is installed, and that installation cross‐subsidisation is pretty significant. It costs a couple of hundred dollars in rural areas to have a telephone put on.

Just as a matter of interest, during the campaign I got some quotes from trenching companies in the Riverina area. These were the companies that dig trenches so you can put in cable, irrigation pipes or whatever. Their standard charge was $1.50 a metre plus travel. That was just to dig the trench. Then you had to have somebody come along and lay the cable, and then you had to have it back filled. I did not get the quotes for that, but those people living out of town will find that, if they do not have the cross‐subsidy on the installation, the installation costs will be prohibitive and way beyond their means—even if they have only a couple of hundred metres of trenching to be dug and cable to be laid.

We also need to look very carefully at what some of the cross‐subsidisation amounts are. In the Bega and Cooma areas, they are between $500 and $900. When you go to places like Nyngan, Cobar, Broken Hill or Bourke, the amounts are different. In Broken Hill, people are subsidised $3,010 per line per year. In Bourke, it is $2,710 per year.

I am told that Telstra actually cross‐subsidises at a rate higher than they are required by law to do, so they are actually giving an additional cross‐subsidisation. That will go when the profits have to be maximised for the taxpayers. Those are the sorts of figures we are talking about. Those are the sorts of imposts that are at risk with the partial sale of Telstra.
I would commend to honourable senators last Friday's Australian Financial Review article by Ivor Ries. The article, headed `One phone bill that's too big', said:

If you reckon that a third of Telstra is worth $ 8 billion (the figure given by the Government yesterday), the most that can come from offshore at the time of the float is $2.8 billion. The other $5.2 billion must come from dinky-di Aussies.
Raising $5.2 billion from local institutions and mums‐and‐dads is a tall order at the best of times.

The most recent mega‐float of this sort was Woolworths, which raised $2.45 billion, and which was over‐subscribed several times. But the key point there was that most of the oversubscriptions came from overseas fund managers.
Clearly the Telstra partial sale will be pushing Australia's domestic fund‐raising ability to the limit.
It then goes on:

The largest amount of new equity raised in Australia in a single year was $18 billion, and that was during the mania that proceeded the 1987 crash. Even then, most of that cash came from rights issues and other forms of capital raising rather than from initial public offerings.
It then goes on to talk about the difficulty of rustling up $5.2 billion from local investors and how that contrasts with overseas demand. It says:
Telstra could be sold several times over to foreign institutions, most of which rate telecommunications companies near the top of their core investments.
That is a very important point to remember when people talk about the sale of Telstra.

SPEECH.PARA: In making my address‐in‐reply to the Governor‐General's speech—it essentially sets down the economic course of our government for its term in the parliament—it is worthy to note that on 1 July in another parliament of this country a new course is going to be set down that will fundamentally redirect, if not disrupt, our social and moral norms. I am referring to the Northern Territory Euthanasia Act. It is very rare that any government influences our lives beyond our economic welfare but, in this case, the Northern Territory act goes to the core of our moral welfare and wellbeing.

The act was first passed on 25 May 1995, was subsequently amended in February 1996 and will commence on 1 July 1996. We already know that there are many people awaiting that July date so they can make use of that act. It should be noted that those who seek to make use of that act are not Northern Territorians. They are from other states such as New South Wales and Victoria. So the significance of this act is that it is going to affect all Australians. I can only hope that in this federal parliament we will not have to deal with the question of Medicare funding for euthanasia.

Apart from the fact that a very tiny parliament of 25 members, representing no more than 3,600 people per electorate, voted for the world's first euthanasia law—and the fact that the parliament of South Australia and the ACT rejected the concept, New South Wales has since shelved a similar bill and no other state has plans for a like debate—what is truly unfathomable is the change of conscience of so many members of the Northern Territory parliament between May 1995 and February 1996. It is unfathomable because the original bill, introduced in May 1995, was so badly drafted that it eventually would have become unworkable. Therefore amendments were very necessary to make the principle of euthanasia work in practice. Those amendments, as I said before, were brought on in February 1996.

You would have thought that this gave those who voted against the bill the first time the very rare opportunity to have a second chance. They could have voted the amendments down, aiming to therefore foil the bill. What is more, based on the initial vote taken in May 1995 and the change in the parliament since, the amendments should have been defeated—yet they were not. All eight members of the government, who had initially, in conscience, voted against euthanasia, voted for the amendments and, therefore, the principle of the euthanasia act came in.

Having involved myself in the debate in the Northern Territory, the greatest disappointment to me was the denial of a true conscience vote for Country‐Liberal Party members on the amendments and, equally, the acceptance by CLP members of that dictum on the matter. The removal of that right was confirmed to me by the Northern Territory Attorney‐General, Steve Hatton, in a letter dated 31 January 1996. I will quote a passage from that address to me. He said:

However the government has taken the view that once an Act is passed by Parliament it is the government's job to make it work and for this reason has opposed the suggestion of a conscience vote on the amending Bill.

That was the reason given by the government. I should say that, nevertheless, credit must go to one member of the Northern Territory parliament, the member for MacDonnell, Neil Bell. Mr Bell has on the table of the Northern Territory parliament a private member's bill to repeal the act, a bill which he seeks to have debated before that very fateful date of 1 July 1996.

Regrettably, this last‐ditch effort to stop the legislation in Australia is likely to fail and, for that matter, is unlikely to even be debated, which really is a measure of the determination of the Northern Territory government to push on with euthanasia and all its consequences. One example of its consequences has already arisen: many ill people, dying people, who have come out publicly and said they will commit suicide by injection under the act will simply not qualify under the act. I do not seek to give the names of these people but simply say that such people gave extensive interviews to the Age in April this year.

The consequences will be either to satisfy their will by a very broad, if not illegal, interpretation of the act by qualified doctors and psychiatrists or that pressure will start to mount to amend the act to widen its catch, particularly for the people who have already gone public. Due to these expectations, it is obvious at these very early stages that both the spirit of the law and the letter of the law will be tested and the boundaries will be pushed to the limit. Whatever fences people have attempted to put around this act or will be put around this act will surely be pushed over.

We legislators know only too well that, once the principle of this type of legislation is released into society, it cannot be contained. It and all its consequences would be near impossible to contain. That is made doubly hard by the parliament majority resting on a person who does not have the resolve to stop its unintended consequences.

Therefore, it is my belief that the Northern Territory act will operate on new tenets for our society—tenets of hopelessness and neglect. The real fear of legitimising euthanasia is the great uncertainty of where it will lead our society. It will be a very grave error for the sponsors of this legislation to believe that they will ever contain or limit the procedure to the so‐called aged and frail, particularly as the act encompasses 18‐year‐olds.

There is something very chilling about a health system encompassing 18‐year‐olds that normalises the act of suicide. That is what our society will be doing if it accepts the Northern Territory euthanasia act. Once we normalise the state of hopelessness, we will accept the very broad concept of suicide. After all, suicide is only ever chosen when the state of utter hopelessness is reached.

I would have thought Australia already had a tragic problem with suicides. That has now surpassed even the deaths on our roads. Incredibly, the statistics for those between the ages of 18 and 25 rank highest in the world. We are really obliged to commit our funds and our social resources to tackle this problem, as we do in every other sphere of great concern in the health system, rather than promote the final solution.

We need to ask: where will society draw the line when it abandons life for self‐induced death in the face of hardship? After all, what is so different about promoting euthanasia as a remedy to physical despair and accepting suicide as a cure for emotional despair? It should be said that, for every shining example of benevolent active euthanasia that the proponents of euthanasia hold up, there is a compelling case where life has been disregarded all too easily.

The critical point here is that there is a clear difference between the right of a person to accept their fate by refusing massive amounts of medical treatment and the choice and administration of medicines that kill. While this distinction is clear and presently legislated for, it is beyond the capacity of legislators, commentators and academics to distinguish between the very blurred lines of manslaughter, coerced suicide and active euthanasia that will inevitably develop under this act.

Society will propel itself on a very perilous adventure if it chooses to accept the philosophy of death by request. A democratic society should demand of all its leaders the unequivocal endorsement of the sanctity of life. Beyond all rights must be the right to life. A creed of rights which omits this is no creed of rights at all. I call upon the Northern Territory government to at least allow discussion about and debate of Mr Bell's private member's bill.

I trust that the government will take this matter on board so that Australians who are held in overseas prisons, especially those Australians with long sentences, are given some hope of returning to familiar surroundings of their own country, even though they may be completing their sentences and not have the freedom of movement of their fellow Australians.

It is necessary to reply to those who hold that Australians should complete their sentences before returning to Australia. A most distressing aspect of having a family member imprisoned overseas is that many people simply cannot afford to go overseas to visit their loved ones. Some do make supreme financial sacrifices to keep in touch, but even then they can see one another only on an irregular basis.

If prisoners were allowed to complete their sentences in Australia their parents, their friends, their spouses and their immediate families would have more ready opportunities to visit them on a regular basis. If we subscribe to the notion that prisons should be a place of rehabilitation, it could be argued that a person who is going to re‐enter Australian society would be better rehabilitated here than in some overseas prison.

The whole issue of the transfer of international prisoners is more complex than the matters which I have raised this afternoon, including the type of treaties which Australia would need to negotiate, the existing treaties which Australia could enter with little difficulty and the resources necessary to bring the scheme into fruition. I have, however, outlined why we as a nation should legislate so that we do not remain the odd nation out in this area of prisoner transfer. I look forward to the government introducing the necessary legislation at an early date.

Before I turn to the second matter, I would like to comment on an article which was carried in the Australian last weekend entitled `Thai roulette—how drug runners beat the odds'. The article in part states:

In February, an Australian girl was arrested in Bangkok for drug smuggling. A month later, two women and a man were caught. These are the success stories for the police and Customs. But, each year, countless others take their chance—and many get through.

A great part of the article draws a romantic picture of how some Australians can earn $10,000 on one drug run to Thailand. It is a pity the article dwelt so heavily on a person called Mike, who has a mortgage, owns a Holden utility, plays squash once a week and enjoys a beer with his mates after work. Mike may have been lucky in running drugs undetected, but if his illegal actions had been discovered in Thailand someone else would have to pay his mortgage, his Holden utility would be a collector's vintage piece the next time he saw it, squash would become a memory and he would have to do without a beer. Depending on his plea before the courts, he would probably receive a minimum sentence of 25 years or a maximum of life—and in Thailand life means life. Putting aside the immorality of drug smuggling, the lure of tax-free money to become an amateur drug runner is not worth it.

In the article to which I have referred, Mike was reported to have said, `I never once really thought that I might get caught.' These are famous last words. I have visited prisons in Thailand in which Australian men and women are held in custody. They are well run institutions, but they reflect a culture different from ours. Prisoners, quite correctly, are not allowed to forget that they have lost their freedom. The prisons are not, as some may suggest, `Bangkok Hiltons'. For a non-Thai speaker—and I suppose for any person—25 years in a Thai prison takes an awfully long time to pass. For those who are tempted to take their chance to run drugs between Thailand and Australia, my advice is `Don't be stupid enough to give it a second thought.'

I turn now to the second issue: namely, forced redundancies in the Public Service and the consequence of such redundancies in human terms. Most honourable senators would agree that the vast majority of Australia's public servants are conscientious, hardworking officers. Some may have a different personal political philosophy from the government of the day. On the other hand, professional officers can put their political philosophy to one side in the workplace and be loyal to the programs and goals of the elected government. It would be folly to suggest that every position in the Public Service carries tenure, because from time to time old tasks are no longer necessary and new ones emerge. Yet it has been reasonably well accepted that, when an officer's particular tasks become redundant, he or she can usually find another position within the Public Service.

Against this background, public servants make personal decisions based on what they consider is a future which is reasonably predictable. They make major decisions to obtain a mortgage to buy a home or shift place of residence for the good of the Public Service and their career prospects. They enter hire purchase agreements for motor vehicles and other goods, and they make plans for the education of their children. All of these personal matters can be thrown into disarray if the stability which these public servants reasonably expected is suddenly swept away. This position arises when there are massive reductions in Public Service numbers such have already occurred almost on a daily basis since the resumption of parliament.

The point I would like to make is that the government must look behind the mere statistics of the staff reductions it plans. Behind each statistic is a person—a public servant who may be the only breadwinner in the family—maybe one of a couple who had planned ahead to raise the capital to buy a home; or maybe an older person who has little prospect of gaining a job outside the Public Service. Dreams will be shattered, financial difficulties can occur, and these can impact on the stability of family life.
This impact runs counter to the views expressed by the Governor-General. When opening the parliament, he referred to the family in the following terms:
Reducing the economic pressure on families, especially those with dependent children, is one of the government's most important and pressing tasks.
The government believes that strong family life offers the best support and welfare system yet devised.

If the government really believes in its rhetoric about the family, it should consider the consequences of its drastic staff reductions on the family. To suggest that the staff reductions which have already occurred and those which are planned will have little effect on employment figures is hard to accept. Not only will some public servants lose their livelihood; so too will traders who depend on the custom of public servants to maintain the cash flow which is necessary to stay afloat.

I remind honourable senators what the current government—the then opposition—said about Public Service reductions during the election campaign. In a press release entitled `Meeting our commitments' issued by Mr Costello on 15 February this year, the coalition vowed to secure its savings target of a 2,500 reduction in Public Service numbers `without forced redundancies of Public Service staff'. A day later, in an interview on ABC radio, Mr Costello affirmed the coalition's stance once more when he said, `There will be no forced redundancies whatsoever.'

Electors in the Australian Capital Territory would not even accept this figure of 2,500, returning three Labor members to the House of Representatives, which was against the trend in other parts of the country. However, that undertaking made during the election campaign no longer has any currency. Of course, the government will hold that the situation has changed, but I doubt that it has. I did not realise what a strain the possibility of forced redundancies is placing on public servants until a couple of weeks ago when I was dining with two Canberra based public servants. Their entire conversation centred on what they would do in the event that either was caught up in the coalition's post‐election policy of slash and burn. It is noteworthy that only about 15 per cent of federal public servants are located in Canberra. The consequences of the planned reductions will therefore be felt throughout the nation.

In an interesting twist, only two to three weeks ago my younger son was approached to attend an interview for a position in the Department of Social Security in the Brisbane area. He declined because he was studying full time and plans to complete his law degree this year. Is it a fact that the government anticipates that its policies will leave social security as the only growth area in the Public Service? Perhaps so. I have no doubt that the assault on the Australian Public Service will continue in the coming months. But the point which I must stress is that each one of the persons affected is a real person, most likely a person who has given loyal service as a public servant and who expected to continue to do so. Each has his or her plans for the future which are now in doubt. If the government can do anything to soften the blow and display some compassion, it should do so.

I turn now to the third issue: Medicare. As I mentioned earlier, this universal health scheme has appeal to many Australians, particularly those in low income groups. Shortly before I entered parliament in 1975, the then Labor government introduced Medibank, the forerunner of the system of Medicare which we now enjoy. It was a struggle to introduce Medibank. But, due to the tenacity of Bill Hayden, the objections of many sections of the medical profession were overcome. It was a herculean task for Bill. I recall that, at one stage of the public debate about the possible introduction of Medibank, Bill Hayden said—with tongue in cheek, but indicating the external pressure being placed upon him—that if he became ill he might have to go to a vet.

Prior to the introduction of Medibank, there were millions of Australians who had no health insurance cover and who simply could not afford basic health care. Medibank changed that. But, when the coalition was returned to office in 1975, it altered Medibank so that it became almost unrecognisable. I sat through seven coalition budgets between the end of 1975 and the beginning of 1983. I can recall only one of those budgets which did not in some way assault the original concept of Medibank. It was almost an annual ritual in that period that budgets heralded a new health policy.

It was not until Labor returned that the current system of Medicare was introduced. Although some members of the medical profession have fought a rearguard action ever since, overall Medicare has been regarded as a great success.

During the election campaign, Mr Howard revealed that he was quite aware of the popularity of Medicare. At the National Press Club, three days before the election, Mr Howard stated, `The coalition will fully retain the Medicare system; the coalition will fully retain bulkbilling and community rating.' Now that we have moved forward two months it is hard to be sure, even though those same words were contained in the Governor‐General's speech when he opened the parliament.

There have been suggestions that a co‐payment—an up‐front fee—could be on the agenda. It does not take an Einstein to reach the conclusion, as suggested in the Rand Corporation's study in the United States, that co‐payments would impact on low income persons and their children and on those who are continually in poor health. The coalition government, therefore, should tread warily in adding financial impediments to groups at risk; groups which may find that health care is something beyond their means.

I am fearful that, if a co‐payment—or some other measures to reduce the cost of the health budget—is introduced, we may be heading down a track such as the one followed when the coalition was last in government. After countless changes, Medibank became unrecognisable. The same fate could befall Medicare. But, then again, if the coalition proceeds this way, it will meet the same fate as did the last government that effectively dismantled our universal system of health insurance. The opposition will carefully monitor the government's performance on this important social issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon, Sen David

TALK.START.PARA: —I have very much pleasure in supporting the motion moved by Senator Teague in the address‐in‐reply to the Governor‐General's speech and in saying that I will not be voting for the amendment to that motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of the speakers from this side have talked in glowing terms about the result of the election and I will not cover those grounds again beyond saying that it really was an emphatic result; there was no ambiguity about what the populace wanted and they knew very well what they were voting for.

The point I would add is that I have never experienced such a climate as has existed out in the electorate since the election. Even two months after the election there is still an undisguised air of relief in the community. There is an air of hope and there is an expectation that Australia will once more get back on the right rails and deliver increasing living standards year by year to the people who contribute to the welfare of society and thereby deliver better things to the whole community. I cannot recall an election in my lifetime after which there was this great sense of relief and hope sweeping through the community.

BREAK.PARA: The two issues that we went to the electorate with and that were very important were the economy and industrial relations. The introduction of voluntary unionism, the correction of the anomalies in the unfair dismissal legislation and the elimination of secondary boycotts are all key elements that are essential to preserve the human rights of the citizens of Australia.

We are fortunate in our moves at this time that there has been a progressive shift in public attitudes to the union movement. The union movement has become increasingly irrelevant to the affairs of normal Australians and it has lost the respect of ordinary Australians. When we see on television people such as Ms George, that great friend and soul mate of Senator Kernot, we realise we are dealing with someone whose social and political views have their origins in the 1930s and have not been reconstructed at any time since then. There is overwhelming support in the community for reform of industrial relations and this government will proceed with those moves.

The second important area is the economy. The Labor Party managed to spend $8,000 million a year more than it earned in taxes, excise duties and other levies. That is, the previous federal government was spending in Australia $22 million a day—more than $150 million a week—more than it raised. That money has to be raised from the Australian community and that is why the interest rates in Australia are amongst the highest in the Western world, and why we have such a high level of unemployment.

Business needs money at low interest rates. That is something that members of the Labor Party do not understand because none of them was involved in business before they came into parliament. I was in the United States for a week in January this year and the Ford Motor Company was advertising across the country every night saying, `Buy a new car—4.8 per cent interest on your purchase with 48 months to pay it off.' Very few Australians could attract a loan with an interest rate that would compare with 4.8 per cent.

The overspending of the previous government has to be measured against the great revival that has taken place in the Australian economy. One of the few things that Paul Keating got right was that the economy was improving. In fact, since 1991‐92 the economy has improved by about $120 billion in GDP, and the government take in the form of taxes and other levies has gone up by $45 billion over those few years. Yet the former government still managed to spend $8,000 million a year more than it got in in taxes.

The people of Australia certainly voted to clean up the problems in the Australian community and to modernise the way society operates—that is what they are asking us to do. We can compete with Asia and we can compete with the other economic powers around the world if we get our act together. We do have the resources: we have the resources both in the physical and in the human sense to compete with anyone, provided we do not have both hands tied behind our back, as we had under the Labor Party. Since we are in competition with Asia and other countries in the region and, indeed, right around the world, we have to meet that competition. We cannot live by borrowing money to maintain our standard of living, which was the Labor Party's approach to the economy of Australia.

In this address-in-reply debate, I want to spend some time talking about a report which was tabled in the Senate last week. It was a report by the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee into the crash of RAAF Nomad Aircraft A18‐401 on 12 March 1990. I will give a little bit of history, to start with.

The Nomad was designed and built by the Government Aircraft Factories, GAF, and it was not a commercial success. The RAAF, when it was initially presented to them, rejected the aircraft; because of its aerodynamic qualities, they viewed it as not suitable. The Australian Army, less informed on these matters and less discerning, took it up. But the GAF production of the Nomad was an exercise in bad management all the way through—and no doubt politics by successive governments played a part in covering up mistakes and errors in the production of the aircraft rather than having them corrected the way they should have been in a normal commercial operation.

However, a number of aircraft were produced which were not sold. Towards the end of the 1980s when the move was to convert the Government Aircraft Factories, corporatise and turn it into ASTA and ultimately sell it, GAF wanted to rid itself of this inventory. The government of the day, the Labor government, decided to take over 20 aircraft off its hands by allocating 10 to the army, four to the RAAF, and a number were disposed of overseas in barter payments to other countries. The whole program was very badly managed.

To put it euphemistically, the aircraft through its whole life enjoyed a very bad reputation. We have never had revealed in this parliament the cost of the Hughes Aircraft Corporation's action against GAF. It was presumably the agent in North America, and it was so alarmed at that aeroplane that it took a damages action against GAF. The Commonwealth settled that for quite a large sum of money—how many millions we do not know. But that was a measure of the unsuitability of this aircraft in the roles for which it was designed.

But to return to these four aircraft that the RAAF acquired in the end of the 1980s, two of them were brand new and two of them were used—but those that were used were relatively low time. The particular aircraft in question, production No. 128, LSN‐128, only had 345 hours on it—which is a negligible time—when it was acquired by the RAAF on 18 December 1987. When the air force acquired it, the Government Aircraft Factories asked for the aircraft to be loaned back to it because it wanted do further trials.

It is interesting that, when you read the reports of this inquiry, the initial statement in the board of inquiry was that GAF wanted it back for matters in relation to the Hughes settlement, whereas in the evidence given to the Senate committee it was said that the aircraft was used for drag reduction trials—and there is an inconsistency there. But it went to ASTA, was there for a while and then came back to the RAAF on 4 August 1989. It did very little flying in both positions. It crashed, killing the sole occupant, Flight Lieutenant Donovan, on 12 March 1990.

The RAAF set up an AIT, an accident inquiry team, who reported rapidly on the accident. They then set up a board of inquiry which, again, looked at the accident in more detail and came to some conclusions. The Air Commander Australia, after the BOI had reported, called for another independent engineering inquiry, which was done. Finally, the Ombudsman was requested by the relatives of the deceased, and by the Minister for Defence quite independently, to review the three inquiries: the AIT, the BOI and the independent inquiry.

It is interesting to put on the record the comments that the Senate committee put in its report in relation to those inquiries. In relation to the AIT inquiry, it said that the Ombudsman reviewed its report quite favourably. As to the board of inquiry report, it noted that the Ombudsman had agreed with the main findings:
(a) the likely cause of accelerated cracking in the failed component;
(b) the failure to conduct the S17 Special Servicing as the last opportunity to detect the damaged component; and
(c) numerous instances of defective administration.
It then gave what is a very severe criticism of the board of inquiry, stating:
The Ombudsman, however, believed that the BOI had erred by:
(a) concluding that disciplinary action was not warranted against any person—
and other findings.

In general, the company ASTA, as it was then, was quite negligent in its documentation and handling of the aircraft from a record keeping point of view while it was in its charge. It did not tell the Air Force what it had done with this aircraft. But what it had done was use it for very extensive ground running at high power settings, and use it in such a way that that ground running was particularly destructive with respect to the fatigue life of the tailplane—which ultimately failed and caused the crash. It was so negligent in its record keeping that the initial estimate of time for ground running that it gave the Air Force was for three hours. Later on it lifted that to 177 hours, which is a whole magnitude of difference in time. But even that it thought was a conservative estimate. The maintenance that GAF or ASTA performed on that aircraft and the record keeping was totally negligent, in my judgment.

RAAF project management was not what it should have been. Project management should be a program which draws up all the relevant procedures that have to be followed in relation to the acquisition of the aircraft. This was not a new aircraft from the manufacturer. All the steps had to be taken to modify it and fit it for service to introduce it into RAAF service. That was done in a very, very poor way. It was done, strangely enough for the air force, by three army officers. A lieutenant‐colonel was in charge and he had two junior officers under him, both of whom were graduate engineers in aeronautical engineering. It is clear that all three of those officers lacked the depth of experience in aviation matters—and I am not talking about flying experience or engineering experience—that they really should have had for that job.

The shortcomings of the project management really set the scene for everything that followed afterwards. When the aircraft went to the Aircraft Research and Development Unit—ARDU—at Elizabeth, the maintenance performed there was very much less than thorough. In fact, one could come to no other conclusion than that it was totally disorganised. There were many gates that this aircraft should have passed through from a maintenance point of view. If any of them had been observed in the correct manner the accident would have been averted because the cracking of the tailplane would have been found. I emphasise that point. It was not a matter of one person or one occasion being involved where this should have been picked up. There were many occasions. On every occasion it was not done.

Finally, there was a servicing known as the S17 servicing which the Royal Australian Air Force applies where any aircraft has not flown for 12 months. It is time dependant; it is not dependent upon hours flown. This servicing was due on 6 March 1989. The maintenance unit was advised in February, a month before the crash, that the S17 servicing was due on 6 March. But worse than that, it flagged it as overdue for the six days between 6 March and 12 March, the day the accident happened. That is something that cannot be explained away, no matter what the witnesses said to the committee.

Flying and the maintenance of aircraft is a highly disciplined business, whether it is in the civilian world or the military world. If there is a requirement that an inspection has to be carried out, then it is done. That requirement is either based on the number of hours flown by the aircraft or on the time expired since the last inspection. There is no variation on it. I say that as someone who has been flying for over 30 years and who has owned, operated and maintained my own aircraft for about 25 to 28 years.

If an inspection is due on such and such a date, you do not fly the aircraft for one or two days past that date; you do not even fly it for one minute. The moment that time expires the aircraft is grounded until the test is made. It is one of the great anomalies that the S17 inspection was not carried out, particularly in a body as disciplined as the Australian Defence Force.

It is totally irrelevant to argue, as some of the witnesses did before the committee, that the aircraft had not flown much in the preceding 12 months. The board of inquiry, of course, found that, if that inspection had been undertaken, the accident would have been prevented. I do not want to dissect the report and go through the argument in detail, but I would seek leave to incorporate in my speech an article in today's Age by Karen Middleton which reviews the whole of the report in great detail.
Leave granted.
Only 170 Nomads were manufactured. So far, at least 66 people have died while flying in them.
Why did Glenn Donovan die?

A Senate report last week on an RAAF air crash in 1990 uncovered a litany of errors that, but for the statute of limitations, would have resulted in officers facing a military court. But, as Karen Middleton reports, there are deeper implications in the way the Defence Force investigates its own and the Government put commercial considerations ahead of safety.

In the clear South Australian sky, Flight Lieutenant Glenn Donovan dropped one engine back to idle and gave the other full throttle. He was an experienced RAAF pilot conducting an unusual but approved exercise.
Glenn Donovan did not know that the tail of A18‐401 had been cracked before he left the ground. The stress of his flying test was too much. It fell off and ended his life.

This is defence officials' best guess at what happened when the 31‐year‐old pilot crashed in a damaged and poorly maintained aircraft, leaving his family to level serious culpability allegations along a chain of responsibility stretching back 20 years.
A Senate committee last week closed the book on the death of Donovan with the fifth in a line of reports on the 12 March 1990 crash of his Australian‐designed and built Nomad aircraft.

What it confirmed was that a disgraceful string of bad decisions, poor maintenance, lazy paperwork and lack of follow‐up contributed to the crash. It found five defence personnel should have been charged under military law for dereliction of duty but were not and, because of a statute of limitations, never will.

The Senate committee also found that the RAAF, Aerospace Technologies Australia (which designed and built the Nomad in its previous guise as the Government Aircraft Factory) and the Civil Aviation Authority all failed to conduct that proper checks in which Flight Lieutenant Donovan put his daily trust. Nobody in either ASTA or the CAA was held responsible. Given the passage of time, the committee thought it was pointless trying to find them now.

Donovan's death uncovered a web of failures by others in the care of his aircraft. It also raised questions about the safety of the Nomad and the legislation and attitudes that govern the way the Defence Force handles breaches of discipline and of law.
Donovan's brother, Philip, a former RAAF instrument fitter who works on the Qantas flight simulator, wanted the committee to examine the wider issue of the airworthiness of all Nomads.

But its terms of reference restricted it to that particular crash only and action specific to that aircraft. The committee did not investigate whether the Nomads in the Defence Force could be fundamentally unsafe. It has not decided whether to table the submissions it has received on the wider issue.
One, obtained by The Age , was from Mr Charles Marshall, a former principal aeronautical engineer with the navy, a former wing‐commander in the RAF and a World War II bomber and test pilot.

Mr Marshall was scathing at the committee's lack of expertise to handle such an important and complex case, labelling it a "farce" because it looked only at maintenance and not the "failure of design, through life monitoring of defects, structural testing surveillance and acceptance". He listed 24 points—many requiring evidence from the designer, Mr Alan Wrigley—which needed to be covered before the committee could properly determine responsibility for the tail failure and apportion blame. Mr Wrigley was not called to make a submission.

In fact, none of the investigations into the crash of A18‐401 examined the wider questions, despite the existence of secret flight‐test reports dating back to 1979 that found that the Nomad had "many fundamental handling deficiencies which seriously compromised flight safety".

A minute leaked to The Sydney Morning Herald last year showed that the Government of the time knew of the Nomad's problems. The then head of the Defence Department, Sir Arthur Tange, wrote to the then minister, Sir James Killen, in June 1979, warning that the public release of the flight‐safety reports would have a "catastrophic commercial effect".
Modifications were recommended and made to the Nomad in response to the identified problems but some ADF pilots do not believe they have solved them.

The Nomad was the pride of Australia's defence industry when it was produced in the early 1970s but did not sell as well as was hoped and only 170 were manufactured. Since then, at least 66 people are known to have died in Nomad air crashes worldwide, although statistics are hard to come by. Even more difficult to quantify accurately is the number of formally reported "incidents" involving the Nomad. ASTA has argued that the Nomad's accident record is comparable to other aircraft of similar size.
This is supported by the fact that many of the recorded Nomad accidents have been attributed to pilot error or bad weather conditions.
But the implications of a formal finding that the Nomads might be badly designed or manufactured could nevertheless expose the Federal Government to legal claims from around the world.

After a series of investigations into the A18‐401 crash, the Defence Force pilots whose job it was to fly the army's Nomads mutinied. In November 1994, the Nomad was formally grounded for military purposes, although it was deemed after review to still be airworthy for civil aviation.
The Defence Force now has 25 Nomads for sale. Many will be sold to private‐sector operators but up to half are being marketed at foreign governments for use by their defence forces.
Some civil operators have defended the Nomad and accused the ADF of prejudice against an essentially safe aircraft.
Donovan's plane was certainly not safe. It began its life at ASTA as a test aircraft. In 1987, it was transferred to the RAAF but lent back to ASTA for its testing program.

The RAAF did not supply the required maintenance report on handover and consequently ASTA did not supply one when it handed it back two years later. In the meantime, ASTA's record keeping was atrocious. It filed the required monthly reports only twice and focused on flying hours, not taking proper account of the stress caused by hours of running the aircraft on the ground.

Consequently, A18‐401 was far more worn than it looked on paper. On the aircraft's return to the RAAF, it did not receive recommended modifications because there was no funding to modify used aircraft, only new ones. A major service which headquarters suggested (later arguing that this was an order) was not conducted.

A less comprehensive service was due on 6 March 1990. It was six days overdue when the aircraft crashed. For some considerable time, the tailplane had been cracked. Most investigations into the crash found that either service, if conducted properly, would have found the cracks.

On top of this, the Civil Aviation Authority received a major defect report from a commercial operator which said almost all its Nomad fleet had experienced cracking, apparently through normal use. It wrote to ASTA with an urgent list of questions. When there was no reply, it wrote again. Although no reply to the letters ever came, the CAA did not follow up the issue. This was nine months before Donovan's accident.

On the afternoon of 12 March 1990, Donovan's wife, Bronwyn McIntyre, had the television on. To her horror, it flashed up the wreck of a Nomad which had crashed 25 minutes earlier at Edinburgh Air Base. She rang the base and was given non‐committal answers until a team of officials and grief counsellors arrived at her home to convey the devastating news according to proper procedure.

It was not the RAAF's fault that a television network's helicopter had been flying in the area and had captured and aired footage of the crash site before the RAAF could inform Ms McIntyre that she had lost her husband.
It was simply the tragic last chapter in a volume of appalling judgments and fatal mistakes, a chain of events in which everything went wrong that possibly could have.

The ADF says the A18‐401 crash was a tragic "one‐off". The ombudsman, the Senate committee and the Government all accept that the institutional procedures that failed have been overhauled so they will not fail again.
But others believe the Government needs to take a long, hard look at the Nomad and take greater responsibility for its litany of problems and their potential to cause further loss of life.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators from Western Australia, but not exclusively from Western Australia, will be saddened to learn of the death of Robert Riley, the former chief executive officer of the Aboriginal Legal Service in Western Australia. I am pleased that both Senator Chamarette, who moved a notice of motion the other day, and Senator McKiernan, who spoke on the adjournment last week—and edged me out because I was trying to do the same thing but ran out of time—have spoken on this matter.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Riley was only 41, yet his achievements were outstanding both personally and for the Aboriginal people of his state and of the nation. We now know something of the personal pain and tragedy which he endured as a child but which, with his immense courage, he overcame to attain the respect and affection of a wide range of Aboriginal and non‐Aboriginal people.

One of my state parliamentary colleagues in Western Australia worked with Rob Riley behind the counter at the old Beaufort Street courts in Perth in the mid‐1970s. He tells me that the 18‐year‐old Rob Riley's compassion and intelligence were obvious from the day he started work.

He did his bit to mitigate the harshness of the criminal justice system on the lives of both Aboriginal and non‐Aboriginal people by ensuring people got extra time to pay fines rather than serving time in default. He was courteous and fair to the public, who were often distressed or confused about court procedures. His honesty was plain to everyone. It was ironic that both he and my parliamentary colleague were both once wrongly suspected of stealing some petty cash at the court. Despite the intensity of the police interrogation and inquiries, Rob Riley maintained no bitterness towards the police or other government authorities despite what he had suffered and what many Aboriginal people in Western Australia continue to suffer.

Rob Riley later served in the army and then resumed his interests in the criminal justice system when he started work for the Aboriginal Legal Service of Western Australia. He served in senior positions in the ALS, lastly as its chief executive officer. Between those periods he held a range of senior positions, including national chairman of the National Aboriginal Conference and head of the issues unit of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. The success and respect the ALS of Western Australia has attained in Western Australia was largely due to his leadership and persuasive advocacy on behalf of Aboriginal people.

The pressures of being a recognised spokesman for the Aboriginal community were immense. He juggled the demands and high expectations of the Aboriginal community with the harsh realities of state and national politics. He denounced the venomous law and order rhetoric that afflicts state politics in this country with unassailable reasoning backed with statistics and a passion for justice. He exposed the futility of politically expedient punitive legislation which condemned Aboriginal and non‐Aboriginal young people to institutions and prisons and to fates he knew too well. Despite this, he saw value in everyone. He believed reasoned debate with even the most entrenched opponents would perhaps leave the opponent a little less entrenched and alert the general public to the positive things we could do as a nation to bring justice to the lives of Aboriginal people.

BREAK.PARA: That he made so many friends and gained the respect of so many people from Prime Ministers to police officers is a tribute to his personal skills and dedication to the improvement of the lives of his people and his love for his country. I am sure senators will join with me in expressing our sympathy to his family and friends at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
